DOC.HEAD: Woman Pleads No Contest to Theft of Rare Books
DOC.TEXT: A former part-time library worker at the University of Pennsylvania pleaded no contest to stealing almost $1.8 million in rare books and documents and to pilfering records to cover up the thefts. Kathleen Wilkerson, 34, entered the plea Friday in Common Pleas Court. She was accused of stealing 101 books and documents, including a rare poem by Elizabeth Barrett Browning, from the university's Van Pelt Library over five years. Ms. Wilkerson was arrested Feb. 28 after she tried to sell six books through a rare-book dealer. The volumes included a $1 million 1611 edition of ``Hamlet,'' which was the library's most valuable printed book. Ms. Wilkerson's attorney, Dennis Eisman, said Ms. Wilkerson pleaded no contest to theft by unlawful taking and tampering with records because of ``long-term mental illness.'' She remains free on bail pending sentencing early next year. The theft was discovered by a Baltimore book dealer, who saw the books in the Bauman's Rare Books in Philadelphia, where they were being evaluated. He suspected they were stolen and contacted the university. From August 1989 to February, Ms. Wilkerson tried to sell 61 stolen volumes to Bauman's, according to Assistant District Attorney Denis Cohen Many of the stolen books were recovered in Ms. Wilkerson's Philadelphia apartment and have been returned to the university, Cohen said. Library officials still are trying to determine if all of the stolen books have been returned.

DOC.HEAD: Stolen Painting Recovered In Brooklyn Apartment
DOC.TEXT: A $320,000 French painting snatched from a gallery wall was recovered in a New York apartment, police said Sunday. A 46-year-old man was arrested and charged with burglary. The canvas by Maurice Utrillo was one of several found at the apartment in Brooklyn, said Sgt. Norris Holloman, a police spokesman. Police didn't know if the other paintings - estimated to be worth up to $1 million along with the Utrillo - also had been stolen. Balazs Gabor was arrested and charged with burglary and possession of stolen property. The Utrillo painting, ``Rue a Montmartre,'' a 1926 work showing a Paris street and valued at about $320,000, was stolen Tuesday afternoon from the Soufer Gallery in Manhattan. A man was let into the gallery, grabbed the painting off a wall and fled, said Gregory Smith, an independent adjuster who represents the painting's insurer.

DOC.HEAD: Supporters for Helms and Gantt Clash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with supporters of both candidates filing assault charges stemming from scuffles at rally Saturday. Pick up 11th graf pvs, `Both candidates...
DOC.TEXT: Supporters of U.S. Sen. Jesse Helms and challenger Harvey Gantt filed assault complaints against each other Sunday after a confrontation at a rally Saturday for the Republican incumbent. Supporters of Gantt, who is black, gathered outside the meeting of backers fo the conservative Helms in a campaign that has become increasingly acrimonious and racially charged. Some Helms backers called Gantt supporters communists and shouted other epithets as they walked through the crowd to the rally. ``Murderer! Murderer! Murderer!'' yelled another Helms backer, in reference to the abortion rights position of Gantt, a Democrat, and some of his supporters. Police were not present during the clash at Alexander Graham Junior High, but on Sunday, three people filed misdemeanor assault charges stemming from minor confrontations or scuffles. Gantt backer Tracy Parker, 19, charged that she was pushed by the Rev. Joseph Chambers, pastor of Charlotte's Paw Creek Church of God, when he took away a poster. The minister, who is the leader of the conservative activist group Concerned Charlotteans, denied the allegation. Gantt supporter Tom Tritten, a university student, and Jim Grice, who was working for the Helms group as a security guard, filed simple assault charges against each other after a scuffle at the rally. The confrontations took place when about 40 Gantt supporters waved anti-Helms signs in the faces of backers as they entered the school. Spokesmen for both campaigns said they were unaware of the confrontation. Police said no arrests were made and no injuries were reported. Helms was foregoing any campaigning Sunday after a long day on the road Saturday, said his wife, Dot Helms. ``We got to bed at 3 o'clock and we're just using this as a day of rest,'' she said. ``I'm sure the Lord will understand,'' why they missed church. Gantt was in church Sunday morning and led a rally in Mecklenburg County on Sunday night. Both candidates planned to fly around the state Monday in a final blitz before Election Day. Polls released Thursday showed a close race between Helms, a three-term Republican, and Gantt, a Democrat. One poll gave Helms a lead of 4 percentage points; another gave Gantt the same lead. Both had margins of error of 3.5 percentage points. Gantt, 47, rode the civil rights wave of '60s to become the first black student at Clemson University and later the first black mayor of Charlotte. Helms, 69, rose to prominence in the same decade as a television commentator who nightly railed against civil rights, integration and communism. That notoriety helped him to the U.S. Senate in 1972.

Put in a Pinch by the Gulf Squeeze, Consumers Start Bargain Hunting
DOC.TEXT: Commuters are sharing rides to work. Travelers are shortening their vacations. Homeowners are switching from oil to gas. With the Persian Gulf crisis three months old and winter approaching, Northeastern consumers are trying to cut costs as fuel prices climb. ``People are concerned,'' said Dave Goodsell, a marketing specialist with the non-profit Caravan for Commuters, which provides free information for Massachusetts residents seeking to form van pools. ``They are ready to make a change because they want to save money.'' Caravan had 700 phone calls - a 46 percent increase - to its information line in August, the first month of the fuel crunch, Goodsell said. He expects similar increases for September and October when those numbers are tabulated. At The Rideshare Co. in Hartford, Conn., inquiries from people seeking car pool information increased 15 percent over this time last year, said Byron L. York, vice president of marketing. Many travel agents report customers are shaving days off trips and looking even harder for bargains. ``One thing we've noticed in the last 10 years is vacations are no longer considered a luxury,'' said Art Kinsman, a manager at the American Automobile Association. He said he has seen many travelers shorten trips and choose domestic, rather than international, destinations. And when people are at home, they're also looking to save money. ``Our companies are receiving double, triple and in some cases tenfold increases in requests for information about customer conversions'' from oil to gas heat, said Thomas Kiley, president of the New England Gas Association. ``The interest has mushroomed and it can be targeted right back to the events of the Middle East.'' The association represents 26 gas distributors in six New England states. They serve more than 2 million customers. Michael Netkovick, spokesman for Energy North in Manchester, N.H., which supplies 80 percent of the natural gas in that state, said business has been up since August with at least 200 customers converting to natural gas from oil. Laurie Hanson, a spokeswoman for Con Edison in New York, said the number of conversion requests from August to October doubled over the same period in 1989. In New Jersey, Public Service Electric & Gas Co. said about 3,600 consumers had switched from oil to gas, a 12 percent increase over last year. ``We generally do get more interest in the fall,'' said PSE&G spokeswoman Priscilla Suber. ``But the interest we're seeing now is spectacular.'' Homeowners requesting free energy audits are up 100 percent to 200 percent in Massachusetts, said Rachel Shimshak, policy director of the state's energy office. In an audit, an expert surveys a home and offer money-saving tips. ``That tells me people are really concerned about home heating costs and taking steps to try to save money and energy now, and guard themselves against future volatility,'' Shimshak said.

DOC.HEAD: Belt-Sander Racing: Here's a Sport That's Downright Gritty
DOC.TEXT: Locals at the Triple R bar set aside football and billiards for a sport with true grit: belt-sander racing. Nine competitors and 50 spectators showed up at the biker bar Sunday for the fall national tournament of the sport that turns ordinary power tools into lean, mean racing machines. Winners received T-shirts and trophies. ``Bored contractors need something to do,'' said Dana ``Mad Dog'' McLean, explaining the appeal of the pastime popular among carpenters and motorcyclists. During a race, sanders zoom side-by-side down a waist-high, 24-foot-long plywood track divided into two lanes. With electrical cords draped over the track's side walls, the sanders fly to the finish and slam into foot-thick foam pads. Some of the machines have been clocked at 3 to 3{ seconds, said race organizer Karl Grose. Despite safety warnings by woodworking teachers and power tool manufacturers, racers insist their sport poses little danger. No accidents have been reported. But the track is sometimes showered with sparks when an electrical cord becomes separated from its speeding sander. Belt-sander racing was introduced to Maine after Triple R co-owner Keith Murphy saw it on television about five years ago. ``It was from a bar in California, just a five-minute clip, and I thought, `We've got to try this some time,''' he said. Murphy and his friends built a track, and word of the sport spread. ``Evidently, there are little pockets of racers all over the country, and we're starting to find out about each other,'' Grose said. Racers debate the merits of Makita, Black & Decker or Porter-Cable much like stock car crews argue the performance of Fords and Chevys. Others tinker with their sanders in hopes of making them a fraction of a second faster. ``A stock Craftsman, right out of the box,'' said McLean, pointing to his racing machine. Racers also are of two minds on the fastest sandpaper. Some prefer coarse for a firmer ``bite.'' Others say finer grit provides more surface contact. Belt-sander racing rules were lax in the sport's early days. ``It was no holds barred, cheating was encouraged, you could reach out and cut the other guy's cord,'' Grose said. ``Now, we modified it to one rule - You can't mess with the other guy's sander.'' Otherwise, he said, ``we're pretty much winging it.''

DOC.HEAD: Capital Murder Defendant's Plight Draws Attention in Germany
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: In Germany, Ricky Morrow's plight is the stuff of passionate demonstrations and letter-writing campaigns. But in Dallas, where he is awaiting the start Thursday of his third murder trial for a killing he admits to committing, most people don't even know his name. Morrow is being tried on capital murder charges in the January 1982 death of a security guard. He says the shooting occurred accidentally while he was trying to rob First Texas Savings and Loan. ``I'm not innocent of a crime. I'm innocent of capital murder,'' he says from his jail cell in Dallas. Under Texas law, a killing during the commission of a felony can bring the death penalty. ``We are trying to do everything on our side to save Ricky,'' says Eva Marie Kaifenheim of Munich, Germany, who has orchestrated a letter-writing campaign that has resulted in more than 200 notes to members of the U.S. news media, officials and diplomats. The letters accuse prosecutors of acting improperly in Morrow's case. Ms. Kaifenheim said she learned of the case through the human rights organization Amnesty International, which employs her sister and other family members. Last year, more than 500 demonstrators marched through the Bavarian capital bearing placards saying, ``Life for Ricky Morrow,'' Ms. Kaifenheim said. ``There are a lot of people here in Munich aware of wha is going on in Dallas,'' she said. Morrow's initial November 1983 capital murder conviction in the death of Mark Frazier was overturned by the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals in March 1988 because of an improper question posed to prospective jurors. A second trial ended in a mistrial in July 1989. ``It was a complete accident, something I never intended to happen,'' Morrow said of the shooting. ``I was drunk, I was on psychiatric medication, I had just been released from a hospital seven days before. ``In my own mind, I do not think that it would be any more wrong for me to die than it was for him. ... He should be living today and would be living today had I not gone out and got drunk and decided to rob a bank. But I did and it happened.'' But he questions the zeal with which he is being prosecuted, noting that Dallas County prosecutors have never lost a capital case since the death penalty was reinstituted in 1976. ``There's a reason they have never lost one,'' Morrow said. ``They will do anything. ``They're spending millions and millions of dollars just to get a notch on their belt. That's what capital cases in Dallas County are all about.'' Chief Assistant District Attorney Norman Kinne confirms that his office has won all 49 capital murder cases tried since 1976. Morrow, 39, of Houston, and Ms. Kaifenheim contend the district attorney's office has resorted to perjured testimony, intimidation of potential witnesses and other unethical acts to ensure the death penalty. Ms. Kaifenheim rattles off the names of wrongfully convicted inmates Randall Dale Adams and Lenell Geter, who were freed by the courts amid allegations of misconduct by Dallas County prosecutors. Morrow said prosecutors refused a plea bargain that would have kept him behind bars, without possibility for parole, until the age of 70. Assistant District Attorney Dan Hagood, who is prosecuting Morrow, declined to respond to the allegations. ``I can't talk about a pending case. Ethically, you are not supposed to,'' he said. But he confirmed his office has received letters from the Germans. Morrow's attorney, Keith Jagmin, also declined to discuss the trial, which started in July with jury selection. Ms. Kaifenheim said she obtained the name of Morrow, who then was on Texas' death row, and that of another death row inmate in 1987 from her sister, Antonie, who works with Amnesty International. The human rights organization unconditionally opposes the death penalty, said Alli Miller, Amnesty International USA's director of programs against the death penalty. Amnesty members in one country are asked to ``adopt'' another country. In this instance, Germany has ``adopted'' the United States and protests U.S. death penalty cases, Ms. Miller said. But the action undertaken by Ms. Kaifenheim was at her own behest, not the group's, she said. Amnesty International does not become involved with capital cases until the defendant has been sentenced. After obtaining Morrow's name and address, Ms. Kaifenheim sent him a letter and a fruitcake for Christmas in 1987. ``Ricky wrote me saying he was very happy for the cake, but even happier by the letter,'' she said in a telephone interview from Munich conducted in German. ``She had also sent some other inmate the same thing and he never responded. I did respond because it was something you don't get in prison and I was moved by it,'' Morrow said. That initial contact sparked a correspondence that has intensified over the years. Ms. Kaifenheim said that during a bleak period a year or so ago when Morrow tried to take his own life, she wrote him daily to boost his spirits. She plans on coming to Dallas when the trial begins. ``I will be in court each day,'' she said. Morrow said Ms. Kaifenheim's concern renewed his interest in fighting for what he calls a fair trial. ``Her primary concern is the same as mine, that I get a fair trial, and that's all I'm asking for,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Women, Stirred By Crisis, Wait For New Freedom
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY20 Nov. 4.
DOC.TEXT: On weekends by the Red Sea, women in head-to-toe black shrouds picnic discreetly beneath umbrellas. These days, however, some prefer bare knees as they blast along on jet skis. Times are changing for Saudi women, but those who will speak out on the subject disagree sharply over how much and how fast. The Persian Gulf crisis, most say, is accelerating a process already under way. ``We've been spoiled with an easy life and never thought about independence,'' said Faiza Ambah, a Saudi reporter for the Arab News. ``If war breaks out, we are going to have to depend on ourselves.'' She shares a newsroom with men but covers her hair and clothes with black wraps. Her bookshelf contains Danielle Steele's ``Changes,'' but she is careful to note she brought it in for a friend. In Saudi Arabia, women have equal rights but far fewer privileges than men. They cannot drive or expose their skin to public view. They can work but, with rare exceptions, not around men. Men and women together, in cars, on the street or in restaurants, must be married. Dating and parties are strictly chaperoned and only take place behind the walls of private homes. Transgressors risk at least a rap on the arm from an Islamic vice squad, if not a term in jail. Women began school only in the early 1960s, when Saudi Arabia also abolished slavery. ``You can imagine the pressure,'' said an Egyptian diplomat who knows Saudi Arabia. ``Girls come home from Berkeley with a drivers' license and a degree and cower from some old man with a stick.'' Well before the gulf crisis, major shifts were under way. Women nurses were allowed to work with men doctors in hospitals. Now half the medical students in Jiddah are women. Years ago, some banks opened all-women branches. Now there are banks operated by women that lend money at a burgeoning pace to women who are opening shops, cooperatives and small businesses. When U.S. troops arrived, a favorite topic was all the women in uniform, liberated professionals who slung rifles over their shoulders, manhandled heavy trucks and barked orders at men. But foreign troops have been kept out of sight, and women soldiers wear modest civilian dress when they have to appear among Saudis. More visible are nearly 100,000 Kuwaiti women, traditionally far freer and more outspoken. As refugees, some attempt to observe local customs, but their attitudes are not masked by veils. Opinions vary widely over the weight of these outside forces. ``Anything is possible as long as it is done discreetly,'' said a Saudia Airlines stewardess, explaining how women forbidden to drive can frolic on jet skis in prohibited swimwear. ``The religious police don't go out on the water.'' A young hospital worker, educated in the liberal climate of Egypt, wears eye-popping bodices under her black abaya on the rare occasions she gets out at night for dinner with friends. ``I don't think things will change much,'' she said, clearly distressed at the thought. ``The Saudis are used to it, and they like it.'' But Rabaa al-Khateeb, who teaches Shakespeare at Jiddah's Abdul Aziz University, argued in a ground-breaking article for the Arab News that it was time to rethink the role of Saudi women. She wrote that Saudi Arabia could not continue ``suppressing the talents and stifling the abilities of one-half the society.'' With or without a crisis, she said, Saudi Arabia will have to employ its women to develop and thrive. Later, in an interview, she took pains to assure that she was not urging full-blown women's liberation. ``We accept that we are different here,'' she said. ``This is our way of life.'' She said most Saudi women believed that restrictions on their activities reflected a male desire to protect them rather than to keep them in an inferior role. Nihal al-Omari, a Western-educated journalist, works with the Nahdha Philanthropic Society in Riyadh which marshals women volunteers for health and social services. She sees important recent strides but a long road ahead. ``All the changes that have been happening lately,'' she said, ``all could go back to before.'' Even among the younger generation, pressure for immediate change is cautious, often muted, and expectations are few. ``We feel safe here, taken care of,'' said Aisha, one of eight young women, mostly students, who gathered at a private home to tell an American reporter how they looked at their future. Aisha, raised in Detroit by Saudi parents, returned only three years ago but settled into the lifestyle of Jiddah. Although she still visits the United States, she prefers Saudi Arabia. She said she was comfortable with a system where fathers and brothers had a say in whom she married and forbid Western-style dating. Her father has two wives, and she thought that worked well. ``It's better than fornification,'' she said, looking around to see if that was the word she meant. A friend corrected her: ``Adultery.'' But Leena, also educated in America, wanted more job openings for women, a greater say in how she shaped her life. And, like most Saudi women interviewed, she wanted to drive. ``The crisis will make the process quicker,'' she said. ``It has opened things up.'' Asked about priorities, one woman said: ``Freedom of speech would be nice. Don't quote me.'' After an hour's debate, most agreed they were content but would welcome change. Leena explained, ``We want to take some of the best you have (in the West) -your way of thinking - but with the protection and stability of our way of life.'' Aisha said: ``Our rulers do what is right. I just wish they would do it a bit faster.''

DOC.HEAD: Change Is Coming in Albania
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: By opening the door of reform just a crack, Albania's Communist leaders have stirred hopes for change that ultimately may bring them down. For many Albanians and foreign observers the only questions are when and whether the fall will be slow or sudden, peaceful or violent. Scores of foreign reporters were in Tirana for an international conference last month, and Albanians of all ages reached out to the visitors with a thirst for freedom and friendship. It was the latest stage of a process that began in May, when the government promised reform. Two months later, thousands of Albanians clambered into foreign embassies, demanding and receiving the right to emigrate. President Ramiz Alia and the secretive elite that runs Albania pulled back from reform. Conflicting articles in the official media suggested a conflict between conservatives and liberals in intellectual, party and government ranks. Just after the gathering of Balkan foreign ministers, Albania's first international conference, another blow fell: the defection of Ismail Kadare, the country's greatest author and the spiritual leader of reform. In announcing his defection in Paris, Kadare said he had hoped Alia would become Albania's Mikhail Gorbachev, introducing change. Alia and the others denounced as a traitor the man they had held up as an example of isolated Albania's proud achievements. A foreign diplomat, speaking anonymously, said Kadare kept to his Tirana home for weeks during the summer, seeing only fellow members of the elite and keeping his distance from Alia's cautious reforms. While the reporters were in Albania, everyone seemed to be talking of the defection, from a 10-year-old boy in ancient Berat to professional people in Tirana. Most praised Kadare as a great man, but some said he had abandoned Albania in its hour of need. Few doubted he had dealt a heavy, perhaps fatal, blow to the leadership. ``Enver, Ramiz, they are gone,'' a worker said. Alia has edged away from the Stalinist legacy of Enver Hoxha, who ruled from 1944 until his death in 1985. It seems likely that a crackdown would provoke strong response from the 3.2 million people of Albania, who know of the anti-Communist revolutions in Eastern Europe and crave contact with the outside. The official course of ``democratization'' through gradual reform, without abandoning one-party rule, did not work for any of the other Communist parties in Eastern Europe. Albanian leaders appear to bank on what officials describe as the country's special legacy: veneration of Hoxha. His name is emblazoned on hillsides across the land, and his victorious World War II partisans are commemorated on memorials as numerous as the hundreds of concrete bunkers he built to defend Albania. Hoxha was the first Albanian since the revered 15th century hero Scanderbeg, born George Castriota, to win genuine independence for his people. Today's increasingly young population - 77 percent of Albanians are under 40 - is more inclined to take independence for granted. The young are impatient for economic improvement and some of the better life they feel the outside enjoys. ``Europe could and ought to do more for the Balkans, and for Albania especially,'' said a student of English at Tirana University. What course the leadership will take should become clear at the Communist Party congress expected in about three months. Parliamentary elections are expected next spring under a new law that allows the people more scope for nominating candidates. Some diplomats feel those events may be too little, and come too late. If violence accompanies change, it will be in keeping with Albania's turbulent history. Life in the mountains that cover 70 percent of the nation has changed little in centuries. Blood feuds bond the small population in an intricate network of ancient hatreds. There aresigns the leadership realizes action is needed to avert a crisis. The party chiefs of Tirana and the port of Durres, Albania's two largest cities, were replaced in an extensive shakeup that followed the July embassy crisis. In August, the statue of Josef Stalin was quietly removed from Shkodra, a northern town. Street signs are notably scarce along Tirana's central Stalin Boulevard, although the Soviet dictator's likeness still dominates a nearby park. Censorship has been denounced in the state press, but has not disappeared. A degree of private enterprise has been allowed, and there is even talk of making the lek convertible. They are small changes and seem tentative, in contrast to the increasingly bold mood in the streets. Albanians gleefully invited foreign journalists to share a game of cards, a drink, a chat, or dragged them hurriedly homes. Their eagerness made mockery of the slogans plastered everywhere, such as: ``The unity of the party and people is our strength.'' Officials were clearly unnerved by the prying of reporters, but the popular reaction was typified by a Tirana student's comment as two journalists left her and several friends dining and listening to Western rock music. ``Goodbye,'' she said, smiling. ``You have brought great gladness to our party.''

DOC.TEXT: Iraq struck a conciliatory stance on Saturday, freeing four American hostages and three captured French soldiers and promising to release more Europeans. Baghdad also indicated it was working on a new peace plan. On Saturday, Iraq's parliament voted to let the 700 Bulgarians remaining in Iraq and Kuwait leave. Also Saturday, the official Iraqi News Agency said European contract workers stranded by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait now could leave if they wished. INA, monitored in Cyprus, gave no number. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, meanwhile, began a mission aimed at breaking the 3-month-old Persian Gulf standoff. He said he would ``lay the foundation'' for military action against Iraq if economic measures failed to persuade President Saddam Hussein to withdraw from Kuwait. Saddam presided over a meeting of top-echelon officials and army commanders Saturday to discuss military operations in southern Iraq, INA said. There were no details on that gathering. The freed Americans and French soldiers arrived in Jordan aboard the same Iraqi Airways flight from Baghdad. At the Amman airport, they were quickly hustled away by U.S. and French officials. The Americans did not speak to reporters except to say they were tired. Also aboard the flight were about 80 Arab nationals andthree men who identified themselves as Irish. They did not give their names. The French soldiers were flown home and arrived in Paris early Sunday. The Americans also were to fly home Sunday. One of the Americans, Randall Trinh, 49, of Hacienda Heights, Calif., was among the hundreds of foreigners kept at strategic sites as ``human shields'' against potential attack following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. It was not known precisely where he was held. The other Americans were identified as Dr. Abdul Kangi, 50, an Indian-born American from Glencoe, Ill.; Raymond Gales, a diplomat from the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait, whose hometown and age were not immediately available; and Michael Barner, 49, of Woodsworth, La. Iraq said the four were released as a humanitarian gesture because they were ``elderly and sick.'' U.S. Embassy sources in Baghdad said Trinh suffered from a stomach ulcer and Barner had a neurological disorder. No other ailments were reported. Iraq has launched a public-relations offensive regarding treatment of its foreign ``guests,'' as it calls the hostages. It said Saturday it would install international telephone lines at strategic sites where captives are held so they can talk to their families. Last week, Iraq offered to allow hostages' relatives to visit them at Christmas. Iraqi officials have expressed fears the United States will use reports of maltreatment of captives as a reason for a military strike. Western leaders called the selective release of groups of hostages an effort by Saddam to split their alliance against him. A French Embassy spokeswoman expressed appreciation for Iraq's ``good gesture'' of freeing the three soldiers, who were captured Monday. French officials did not disclose the incident until Friday. A French Defense Ministry spokesman said the three were likely to face disciplinary action for their ``act of carelessness.'' France stopped short of admitting the soldiers had blundered into Iraqi territory, but hinted that had been the case. About 13,000 French soldiers are deployed in the gulf region as part of the 300,000-strong multinational force, made up mainly of U.S. troops. Baker arrived in Bahrain Sunday on a trip that also will take him to Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Turkey, Britain and France. His meetings include consultations with Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen in Cairo. The Soviet Union and China are permanent members of the U.N. Security Council and their support would be essential for any additional U.N.-backed steps against Iraq. On his U.S. jet, Baker told reporters he planned to consult over eight days in seven countries with leaders of a wide array of Arab and European nations, including a Moscow stop Thursday to see Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. He said, ``The purpose of the trip is to discuss with our coalition partners strengthening the full range of measures that we have employed to isolate Saddam Hussein ... political measures, economic measures and military measures, and thereby to lay the foundation for the possible exercise of all options. ``This will improve the prospects for peaceful resolution, and, at the same time, permit us to be prepared to consider all options if peaceful ones don't work.'' Also in the region was French President Francois Mitterrand, who arrived in Egypt on Saturday and had a meeting set Sunday with President Hosni Mubarak. The Iraqi foreign minister, Tariq Aziz, arrived in Jordan Saturday for talks with King Hussein, and a senior Jordanian official said Aziz was carrying a message from Saddam on ``ways to achieve peace.'' No details were disclosed. Aziz accused the United States and Britain of ``escalating their war rhetoric and threats.'' But he said there were expressions of interest in a peaceful solution being voiced elsewhere. There was word of a planned Iraqi peace initiative from Irish and Italian parliamentarians, who met with the speaker of Iraq's ruling National Council. They said the Iraqi plan calls for the release of all foreigners in return for guarantees from world powers that Iraq will not be attacked. In its Sunday editions, The New York Times quoted Saudi Oil Minister Hisham Nazer as saying Saudi Arabia had pushed its oil production above 8.2 million barrels a day and would reach 8.5 million barrels daily early next year. The Times said that, despite the U.N.-ordered embargo on Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil, the world may now be producing more than it was before the Persian Gulf crisis. On Oct. 31, officials of the International Energy Agency, meeting in Paris, said the world was making enough oil to meet demand. At that time, Saudi oil production was reported to be 8 million barrels a day. In other developments: -Former Japanese Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone arrived in Baghdad Saturday to try to win the freedom of Japanese hostages. Although Nakasone's trip is private, it has the Tokyo government's backing. -European Community foreign ministers will meet Monday or Tuesday in Rome to discuss former West German Chancellor Willy Brandt's planned private mission to Iraq, the Dutch Foreign Ministry said in The Hague. Brandt is going to Baghdad on Monday reportedly to negotiate with Saddam for the release of foreign hostages. The European Community has called for its members not to negotiate separately on the hostages.

DOC.HEAD: Three U.S. Sailors Injured in Bombing at Restaurant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE number of injured, CORRECT time of explosion, upgrade attribution; No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A bomb exploded at a restaurant injuring eight people, among them three sailors from the U.S. aircraft carrier Abraham Lincoln, police and the U.S. Navy said Sunday. No group claimed responsibility for the bombing, which occurred shortly before midnight Saturday in this seaside resort, 180 miles west of Santiago, according to a police statement. In Washington, Navy Cmdr. Stephen Honda said two of the sailors were treated at a local hospital and released, while the third was treated on board the Abraham Lincoln. He said the injuries were limited to cuts and bruises caused by flying glass and other debris. About 40 people were in the restaurant, the Max Moritz, when the bomb went off. They included a group of sailors from the Nimitz-class aircraft carrier, docked in the neighboring port city of Valparaiso on a five-day port stop. The bomb was placed near the kitchen and damaged the restaurant and neighboring buildings, police said without elaborating. Three British tourists and two waitresses were also injured in the attack. One of the Britons was seriously injured, the police statement said. The Abraham Lincoln is transiting around South America as part of a scheduled inter-fleet transfer from the Atlantic to Pacific fleet. It is scheduled to arrive in Alameda, Calif., its home port, in late November. The identities of the U.S. sailors were not released.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Considers Training Warsaw Pact Military Officers
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon may soon be training military officers from the very countries it once viewed as archenemies. The administration is considering requests from members of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact - Poland, Hungary, Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria and Romania - to participate in a program known as International Military Education and Training (IMET), officials say. While the program probably would cost just several hundred thousand dollars, the symbolic value of such a project would be much higher. ``Who would have believed we would train officers from the very countries which we viewed as our enemies just last year?'' said one Defense Department official. The possible training project is just one of many options under consideration by the Bush administration to help countries which this year discarded more than four decades of communist rule. ``Money will be very tight and we're considering a range of things for Eastern Europe,'' said a Bush administration official, who, like the other official, asked not to be named. ``IMET is one of the things that has been thought about.'' That official said the decision on whether to include any East Europeans in the program would not be made until December, when the State Department puts together its budget request for the fiscal year that begins next Oct. 1. The program is funded under the foreign aid bill and administered jointly with the Pentagon. The 1990 program totaled $47.2 million. The size of the individual country programs ranges from a low of $15,000, up to $3.38 million for Turkey. There are more than 800,000 troops in the Warsaw Pact, not counting the Soviet Union. But the alliance is crumbling; it lost one of seven members this year when East Germany merged with West Germany, and Hungary is preparing to leave. Pact members have planned a summit later this year to discuss the alliance's future, with plans to transform it to a political rather than military grouping. Meanwhile, its members have begun reducing the size of their Soviet-armed and trained military to save money for the expensive and painful transition from a state-run economy to a free-market system. The Soviet Union also is trying to save money. Its forces have begun pulling out of Hungary and Czechoslovakia. There are no Soviet troops stationed in Romania and Bulgaria, and those in Poland and the former territory of East Germany eventually will be withdrawn now that Moscow has decided to bring all its troops home. The way for cooperation with the United States was paved earlier this year when NATO leaders agreed to set up regular diplomatic contacts with members of the Warsaw Pact. Since then, diplomats from Eastern Europe have received regular briefings at NATO headquarters in Brussels, mostly about the crisis in the Persian Gulf and about the Soviet Union. NATO is debating how far to go in sharing information with the East Europeans as long as they are still allied militarily with Moscow. The East Europeans, eager for any contact with the West as they restructure their economies and social systems, want more. ``As we move away from the Warsaw Pact, it's clear we have to diversify our military ties,'' said one Hungarian official. He said groups of military historians, lawyers and sharpshooters from Hungary and the United States have paid visits to each others' countries. In September, Poland and Czechoslovakia offered medical facilities for U.S. troops being deployed in Saudi Arabia. Romania offered the troops recreation facilities on the Black Sea, and Bulgaria said it would send troops. Romania also has asked for U.S. advice on setting up a military chaplain's service - something that was outlawed under the atheist communist regime - and on revamping the military judge advocate's office, the officials said. But the United States still has concerns about Romania's human rights record, especially after the government - made up of many former communist officials - used club-wielding factory workers to violently suppress anti-government protesters last June. ``Romania still has to correct its image,'' said one U.S. official. ``They've taken some steps in the right direction.''

DOC.HEAD: This Mountain's High Enough, Authorities Say
DOC.TEXT: Alpine villagers who wanted to rearrange the rocks atop Mount Fletschhorn to restore its original official height have been told to leave the peak alone, newspapers said Sunday. Until 1952, the mountain in southern Switzerland had been formally listed at 13,123 feet, or 4,001 meters. Four thousand meters is considered a psychologial barrier for climbers seeking a challenge. The revision cut its official height to 13,113 feet, or 3,998 meters, possibly due to erosion. Three years ago, the mayor of Saas Grunt launched a drive to move a few rocks around at the top to re-establish the mountain's former height, and possibly make it more appealing to climbers. But environmentalists and climbers' groups, including the Swiss Alpine Club, opposed the idea, urging the mountain be left as it is. Authorities in Valais canton, or state, agreed. The Valais surveyor's office decided Fletschhorn is ``a majestic part'' of the Alps and should remain in its natural state, Sunday's reports said. The village's mayor, German Anthamatten, was quoted as saying he may challenge the ruling. But the newspapers said he probably faced an uphill battle. They said in a recent measurement, the mountain had lost another five feet of height.

DOC.HEAD: President Mwinyi Wins Second Term in One-Party Elections
DOC.TEXT: Ali Hassan Mwinyi has been re-elected to a second five-year term as president of the one-party state, the government announced. Mwinyi received 95.5 percent of the votes cast in balloting Oct. 28, said the chairman of Tanzania's electoral commission, Justice Lameck Mfalila, on Saturday. Mwinyi, 65, is also chairman of the only political party, the ruling Chama Cha Mapinduzi. He was to be sworn in Thursday. Nearly three-quarters of the East African nation's 7.3 million registered voters cast ballots in the poll. Tanzania's 1977 constitution stipulates a president can serve no more than two successive five-year terms. Mwinyi was elected in 1985 when Tanzania's founder, Julius Nyerere, retired.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Raid Northern Outpost, 10 Soldiers Killed
DOC.TEXT: Tamil rebels killed 10 soldiers Sunday in an attack on military outpost that the army had captured from the insurgents last month, military officials said. They said the outpost at a Hindu temple at Mavaddipuram in the northern Jaffna district was attacked three times by the rebels. Mavaddipuram is one of the positions taken during an operation last month to a secure a stronger foothold in the Jaffna Peninsula, the main stronghold of the Tamil Tiger rebels. About 16 square miles were brought under government control, linking several bases that previously had been isolated in rebel territory. The raid Sunday was the first retaliatory action by the rebels to dislodge the troops from their new positions. At least 14,000 people have been killed in the Tamil rebellion since it began in 1983. Tamils, most of whom are Hindus, claim discrimination by the Sinhalese majority who are predominantly Buddhists.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds of Fans Rampage in Leipzig; Police Kill One
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to UPDATE with nine youths seriously injured. Pickup 3rd pvs, `Damage was...'
DOC.TEXT: City officials in Leipzig on Sunday demanded better security at soccer games after rampaging fans smashed cars, looted stores and fought street battles. An 18-year-old man was killed by police, authorities said. Nine youths were seriously injured in the violence Saturday, 80 people were arrested and a police officer was hospitalized, police said. Damage was estimated in the millions of dollars. It was one of the worst soccer riots ever in the former East German territory. The rioting broke out following Berlin's 4-1 victory over Saxony Leipzig. Fans fought pitched battles outside the stadium, then hundreds stormed through the city. About 500 youths squared off with police at a subway station. Police officials said officers fired warning shots, and then a young man was gunned down in what was only described as an emergency situation. The 18-year-old was not identified. One large truck was set afire and at least 12 cars and four police wagons were demolished. The ground floor of a department store was gutted by looting and vandalism, authorities said. A police official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said most of the rioters were from Berlin. City Council President Dieter Gaasenbeek demanded Sunday that police bolster security precautions for soccer games.

DOC.HEAD: Landfill Vote Splits Friends, Families and Neighbors
DOC.TEXT: There hasn't been much friendly banter or cordial conversation at the Blue and Gray Restaurant since a developer proposed turning an old strip mine into a $30 million landfill for out-of-state garbage. ``I've never in my life seen anything like this,'' said Lisa Knotts, a waitress at the popular Main Street diner. ``People used to sit and talk, discuss things. ``Now, they're one way or the other. They're dead set against it or for it.'' Barbour County officials expect a record 90 percent of the struggling coal-mining county's 8,776 registered voters to cast ballots Tuesday to settle the dispute. The vote is the first under the state's new solid-waste law that allows residents of each of the state's 55 counties to block landfills that would accept more than 10,000 tons of trash or more each month. Some people in the north-central West Virginia county said landfill opponents hold a slim lead. Others said the race is too close to call. ``It's not very difficult to find people fixing to fight,'' said the Rev. John Lepp, pastor of two United Methodist churches in the county. ``I don't know what it will take to get people to reconcile. ``I've been told there are some people who are not coming back to my churches because they think I favor one side.'' No blood has been shed, the 56-year-old Lepp said, ``but I don't like the subtle things like not speaking to some people or turning around when they come into a store or a room.'' ``This is the biggest thing to hit Philippi since the Civil War,'' school bus driver Rex Freeman said, referring to the town's claim that it was the site of that war's first land battle. The landfill, proposed last year by Energy Resource Management Services Inc., would be at an old surface coal mine about seven miles west of Philippi, or 135 miles south of Pittsburgh. An average of 7,500 tons of household waste - most of it brought in by train from the Northeast - would be dumped there daily, said John Faltis, the company's chief executive officer. Faltis, who owns the company with a Dutch investor, said they would invest about $30 million to prepare the site. An additional $24 millio would go toward special railroad cars that could haul waste in and take coal out to market. He said he expects to make $200 million profit by the time the landfill is filled in 25 years. Tonnage fees and other charges would inject $5 million annually into the county's sputtering economy and residents would get free trash pickup, said Faltis, who has operated coal mines and other businesses in the area for nearly 20 years. The company has said the landfill will generate more than 200 permanent jobs, paying $8 to $15 an hour. Eighty-five percent of the employees will be from Barbour County under an contract signed by Faltis and the Barbour County Commission last summer. Barbour County's unemployment rate in September was 9.1 percent, compared to the statewide rate of 5.4 percent. The demand for clean, non-polluting fuel has cut the market for the area's high-sulphur coal, and new technology means fewer miners are needed to produce what coal is mined. ``Ten years ago you would have seen 100 working coal mines here and thousands of miners earning close to $40,000 or $50,000 a year,'' Lepp said. ``Those days are long gone.'' Philippi, the county seat, has about 3,100 residents and is home of the private Alderson-Broaddus College. Opponents question the landfill's safety and the wisdom of bringing in huge amounts of out-of-state trash. ``When you get done filling the site 25 years down the road, you're going to have 75 million tons of garbage sitting atop the highest point in Barbour County,'' said businessman Chuck Schnautz. ``We'd be setting ourselves up to receive a 75-million-ton pile of garbage and the current technology can't guarantee that we won't have problems with it.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Commander Of Deadly King David Hotel Attack Dies
DOC.TEXT: Yisrael Levy, an underground fighter in Israel's struggle for independence who carried out the 1946 bombing of a Jerusalem hotel that killed 91 people, has died. He was 64. Levy died Friday and was buried the same day, according to a death notice in the press. The cause of death was not given. Levy belonged to Irgun Zvai Leumi, the militant Jewish underground that, led by Menachem Begin, fought the British for independence in the 1940s. Irgun carried out dozens of attacks on British army, government and police targets. Its deadliest operation was the bombing of the King David, a luxury six-story hotel that housed the British Government Secretariat and army headquarters. The Jerusalem-born Levy, who joined Irgun at age 14 and used the nom de guerre of Gideon, was entrusted with the mission, having already participated in a bombing of British police headquarters in Jerusalem in 1945. ``Giddy's tremendous inventive and creative powers were called upon to the full,'' Begin recalled in his memoirs, ``The Revolt.'' Begin was prime minister from 1977 to 1983. ``It is not simple to penetrate the very heart of the military government ... We were well aware that this was the largest of our operations to date and that it might turn out to be unique in the history of partisan wars of liberation,'' Begin wrote. On the morning of July 22, 1946, Levy and his accomplices entered the La Regence Cafe in the hotel basement dressed as Arabs and planted milk cans packed with 500 pounds of explosives. Levy was reportedly disguised as a Sudanese waiter. No customers were in the cafe. The attackers locked La Regence's 15 Arab workers in a side room and set the timers to go off 30 minutes later. Two British officers who entered the cafe clashed with the attackers and one officer was shot and killed, while the other was wounded. Outside the hotel, an Irgun cover team exchanged fire with British soldiers and then set off a firecracker. In the confusion, the attackers freed the Arabs then fled. ``Suddenly, the whole town seemed to shudder ... the entire wing of a huge building was cut off as with a knife,'' Begin recalled. The 200 casualties included 91 dead, among them senior British officers, 15 Jews who worked for the British government, and several Arabs. The Irgun suffered one fatality. Begin said the Irgun had telephoned warnings to the hotel, the French Consulate and the Palestine Post newspaper about 25 minutes before the blast. The bloodbath resulted in ``days of pain and nights of sorrow'' for the Irgun, Begin wrote. The attack haunted Levy for years, according to friends of his quoted in the daily Yedioth Ahronoth. Levy stayed with the Irgun until it was disbanded in 1948, the year Israel won statehood. He later became a stationery store-owner and lived a quiet life in suburban Tel Aviv. ``He was a modest man, a family man,'' said Yehiel Kadishai, an aide to Begin. ``I don't recall him ever speaking about the (King David) operation.'' He is survived by a wife, two daughters and a son.

DOC.HEAD: Malaysia Gives $5 Million To Mandela To Fight Apartheid
DOC.TEXT: South African anti-apartheid leader Nelson Mandela received a $5 million contribution from Malaysia and other aid pledges before leaving for Brunei on Sunday. Mandela, near the end of two-week tour of six nations, said the money will help fund African National Congress efforts while its leaders negotiate with the government to end racial segregation policies. Mandela, 72, attended a dinner in his honor Saturday in the capital of Kuala Lumpur. He also received other pledges of assistance, including aid to build housing for more than 20,000 political prisoners expected to be released soon. In Brunei, Mandela's last stop on the international trip, he was greeted by Prince Mohamad Bolkiah, the foreign minister of the small Asian nation. On Monday, Prince Mohamad is scheduled to host a lunch in Mandela's honor. Later, Mandela will meet with Sultan Hassanal Bolkiah in Bandar Seri Begawan, the capital. Mandela also visited Australia, India, Indonesia and Japan. Mandela said Australia had promised $15 million; Indonesia $10 million and India $6.5 million. Mandela, however, complained Japan did not make any financial contribution to the ANC. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu said Japan could not provide aid to the ANC because of its policy of not giving assistance to political parties in other nations. But Kaifu told Mandela Japan would provide aid to grass-roots South African groups.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Cheered Along Cambodia-Vietnam Peace Run
DOC.TEXT: Two Americans, one a severely wounded war veteran, said Sunday that Cambodians and Vietnamese offered them water and rest on their 120-mile ``Friendship Run'' between Phnom Penh and Ho Chi Minh City. ``I've been praying for 20 years to come back,'' said Clebe McClary, who in 1968 lost an eye and an arm as a U.S. Marine lieutenant in Vietnam. The run was staged to try to speed reconciliation between the United States and the governments of Cambodia and Vietnam, neither of which Washington recognizes. ``If we don't get together and smile and talk we'll never have any friendship. We caused a lot of destruction in Vietnam and I think we owe them something,'' McClary said. ``Hey man, the war's over.'' The run began Tuesday in the Cambodian capital and ended Saturday in Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon. McClary, 49, and Stan Cottrell, 47, complained of the blistering heat but were effusive in describing villagers offering them hammocks, massages and water. Hundreds of children would follow them along the way, they said. Unarmed Vietnamese policemen escorted them for part of the way but there were no incidents and the two said they felt generally at ease, even in the Cambodian countryside where a guerrilla war rages between the government and three opposing factions. Their longest daily run was 42 miles. A ceremony was held when they reached the Cambodian-Vietnamese border and some Vietnamese joined them for a small segment of the run. McClary, from Pawley's Island, S.C., was making his first trip back to Vietnam since the war, in which he lost many friends. ``Even during the war I loved the people and the country,'' he said. ``I was wounded seven times and had 34 operations and they said I'd never walk again.'' He was on his feet shortly after the last operation in 1969 and 10 years later became an avid runner. He said he wanted to bring other veterans back to Vietnam, perhaps on another run. In the United States, McClary speaks to and counsels high schools, church groups and businesses on leadership and motivation. Cottrell, who lives in a suburb of Atlanta, is a veteran long distance runner. In 1981, he crossed the United States at a rate of 53 miles a day. He also has made peace runs along China's Great Wall, in the Soviet Union and, last July, between Berlin and Warsaw. In 1988, Cottrell completed a ``Vietnam Friendship Run'' from the capital, Hanoi, to the central coast city of Da Nang, near which McClary was wounded. ``I believe that one person can make a difference, that individuals can break down the walls that divide us,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Political Violence Rising Along the Edges of the Soviet Union
LaserPhoto MOSB1
DOC.TEXT: Edik Badalian, a fatigue-clad guerrilla in the mountains of Armenia, raised his 1905 vintage carbine and squeezed off a shot at an imaginary invader from the neighboring Soviet republic of Azerbaijan. ``We usually carry hunting rifles. But we have what we need,'' said Badalian, 38, who also wore a pistol. Members of his eight-man unit showed off a handmade mortar and rocket-propelled grenade launchers, and said they had automatic weapons hidden in the hills. ``We station ourselves around farms and settlements to protect them against Azerbaijanis,'' said Badalian, who works as a construction engineer by day and patrols by night. A few miles away, Soviet troops did sentry duty on the rugged border between Armenia and Azerbaijan, the scene of ethnic clashes for two years. The sealed frontier between the two republics symbolizes the political violence that is rising in distant corners of the Soviet Union as the Kremlin's political authority falls. Last week, two Armenian shepherds were killed on the border and Armenian guerrillas briefly took four Soviet soldiers hostage in retaliation for the detention of several local residents in the embattled enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh. At least three separatists were killed Friday in ethnic strife in the southeastern republic of Moldavia. In the Caucasian republic of Georgia, a politician was shot in the arm two days before balloting on Oct. 28. Over the past 18 months, violence also has struck along the border between Uzbekistan and Kirgizia, the Fergana Valley of Uzbekistan, the Georgian capital of Tbilisi and the Abkhazian section of Georgia. The fighting has helped keep alive rumors that the military and KGB security police might be plotting to crack down against the disorder that has accompanied the reforms of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. One rumor depicts Gorbachev as the leader of the crackdown, another as its victim. In Armenia and Georgia, where passions are running high, people accuse Gorbachev of trying inflame rather than quell the violence. ``The Kremlin is creating another Lebanon in the Caucasus. They want to create the illusion that the Caucasians are fighting among themselves, and that the Russians must go in and restore order,'' said Zviad Gamsakhurdia, who is emerging as the dominant politician in Georgia. Soviet central authorities have balked at open intervention in Georgia since April 9, 1989, when army paratroopers used sharpened shovels to disperse a peaceful rally in Tbilisi, killing 19. The incident sent shock waves through the entire Soviet Union, and shoved Georgia firmly toward a declaration of independence. That momentum was evident in balloting last week as Gamsakhurdia's Round Table non-Communist bloc won control of the Georgian Supreme Soviet legislature on a platform of independence and capitalism. The voting was peaceful, the campaign at times violent. Two days before the electio, Gamsakhurdia's rival, Georgi Chanturia, was shot in the arm. Chanturia accused Gamsakhurdia of arranging the shooting on orders from the KGB. Gamsakhurdia retorted that Chanturia either staged the event or was shot by central authorities seeking to spark civil war. The situation is just as murky in Moldavia. There, the legislature has declared sovereignty from Moscow and talking of reunifying with neighboring Romania, from which it was separated in World War II. But ethnic Russians and Ukrainians have declared their own ``Dniester republic'' in eastern Moldavia, and the Gagauz - a group of Christian Turks - have proclaimed independence in southern Moldavia. On Wednesday, Soviet Interior Ministry troops moved against the Gagauz, and Moldavian Interior Ministry troops clashed with the Russians and Ukrainians on Friday. The lines are not much clearer along the Armenian-Azerbaijani border. The trouble began in late 1988 as Christian Armenians demanded control over Nagorno-Karabakh, a largely Armenian enclave located just over the border in mostly Moslem Azerbaijan. Scores have died in the dispute, and tens of thousands have fled their homes. Last winter the two sides clashed with armor and artillery at Eraskh and elsewhere. Soviet Interior Ministry troops quelled the fighting, and now the only visible armor belongs to central authorities. Sgt. Viktor Rezanov, who commands a 10-member border checkpoint at Eraskh, keeps the machine gun of his armored personnel trained on Armenia. ``They drive by at night sometimes and shoot off their guns,'' said Rezanov, 20, from the Russian city of Chelyabinsk. Squad members wear flak jackets to protect them against snipers or ambush. The heavy armor keeps guerrillas in check, but tension persists, said Lt. Vladimir Pomashkin, 25. ``The biggest threat is from armed people who have no right to be carrying guns,'' said Pomashkin, from the Russian city of Kirov. ``They get a gun in their hands ... and they think they should use it.''

DOC.HEAD: GOP Tries To Avoid Big Losses Tuesday
With AM-Election Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Republicans are spooked by recent negative polls for their House candidates and hope to capitalize on the unpopularity of Congress to avoid heavy losses on Tuesday. ``Praise the president, and bash the Democrat Congress,'' said Rep. Guy Vander Jagt, summarizing his party's message for the final days of the campaign. ``There is a ferocious anti-Congress hostility out there,'' said Vander Jagt, who is chairman of the House GOP campaign organization. ``It's a prairie fire. And it doesn't take too much to shift (the feeling) from against Congress to against those who RUN Congress.'' But party strategists concede that they will have a hard time fully recovering from the decline Republican candidates have suffered in recent polls. Those losses have been based largely on a perception that the party, and President Bush in particular, sought to defend the wealthy against tax increases and then endorsed a package that imposes higher taxes on nearly everyone. ``You've got a big challenge if you want to overcome in 10 days what was three years of an opposite message,'' said Vander Jagt, R-Mich. Bush has been on the hustings peddling the message that the spending cuts in his budget deal with Congress are his, and the new taxes belong solely to the Democrats. Whether that will sell with voters remains to be seen. ``That message, that the devil made me do it, just is not credible,'' said Larry Sabato, a political analyst at the University of Virginia. Polls show that after a precipitous drop three weeks ago, Republican candidates have mostly regained their footing. But there continues to be slippage, particularly in the 29 races for seats where no incumbent is seeking re-election. The open seats are where Democrats have their highest hopes for making gains. Two are virtually certain to move to the Democratic column, and both represent comebacks for former House members. In Arkansas' 2nd District, Ray Thornton is considered a shoo-in, and in Hawaii's 1st District, liberal Neil Abercrombie is expected to win. The party is straining to hold on to previously Democratic open seats in Maine, Florida, New Jersey, Ohio and Texas. But it has a good shot at picking up Republican seats in Connecticut, Iowa, Idaho and Rhode Island. Democratic gains in the polls have been particularly strong among senior citizens and women, leading analysts to conclude that the party's economic fairness message is bringing core Democrats home. Sabato said the net pickup for Democrats may well be 10 or more seats, about twice the shift analysts in both parties had predicted around Labor Day. ``There's a definite drift toward the Democrats,'' he said. The party now holds a 258 to 175 majority in the House, with two vacancies. A 10-seat shift would give Democrats their largest House advantage in more than a decade. But along with the Republicans' partial recovery have come two other phenomena: a day-to-day instability in poll numbers and a marked erosion of support for incumbents in both parties. ``The numbers are jumping all over the place,'' said one Republican operative, citing swings of 10 to 15 points for some candidates. ``The charts look like a seismograph after an earthquake.'' Vander Jagt has told Republican colleagues to keep their guard up if they won with less than 65 percent of the vote in 1988, or if they have an opponent this year who has raised more than $100,000. Incumbents who are used to winning handily may be in for squeakers, and those without a cushion may lose, say analysts in both parties. The Republicans considered most likely to lose are Oregon's Denny Smith, tainted by the savings-and-loan scandal, and Minnesota's Arlan Stangeland, hurt by ethics charges. Also on the endangered list are Charles Pashayan of California and John Hiler of Indiana. In Vermont, trouble for Republican Rep. Peter Smith could well give the House its first socialist member since 1929: Bernard Sanders, the former mayor of Burlington, who is running as an independent. Smith was trailing late last week in private polls. Democrats also have their share of lawmakers in trouble. California's George Brown, Ben Jones of Georgia, Roy Dyson of Maryland and Bill Sarpalius of Texas are among the most vulnerable. Late polls also showed slippage for Reps. Jim Jontz of Indiana and Wayne Owens of Utah. But the volatility that pollsters have been talking about for weeks remains in force. Democratic pollster Geoff Garin said the turmoil is the result of three competing political currents, any one of which could dominate Tuesday's voting. The budget deal and the ailing economy, the country's general anti-incumbent mood and the Persian Gulf crisis all have taken turns at the forefront in recent week. ``I, or anyone else, would be foolish'' to predict a precise outcome, said Vander Jagt. ``This is the most volatile political situation any of us has ever experienced.''

DOC.HEAD: Iranians Mark 11th Anniversary Of U.S. Embassy Takeover
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of Iranians chanting ``Death to America!'' burned the American flag at a rally Sunday in front of the former U.S. Embassy in Tehran to mark the 11th anniversary of its takeover by militant students. Tehran television, monitored in Nicosia, showed a large crowd carrying signs proclaiming ``Death to America,'' ``Death to Israel,'' and ``Death to Britain.'' Young men and women, including university students, converged on the rally site from all parts of the capital, the television said. Musavi Khoeniha, the former prosecutor who was the mentor of the militant students who stormed the embassy 11 years ago, read a half-hour message from Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran's spiritual leader. Khamenei's message urged the country's feuding radical and so-called pragmatic factions to stop their infighting and remain united. Parliament Speaker Mehdi Karrubi, a hard-line opponent of Khamenei, then addressed the crowd, warning against the U.S. presence in the Persian Gulf. He said that ``the capture of the U.S. nest of spies in Iran, guaranteed the future of the revolution, and disrupted America's spying machinery.'' None of Iran's high-ranking leaders showed up at the rally, which commemorates what is considered a turning point in the history of the 1979 revolution. President Hashemi Rafsanjani has been trying to temper the revolution since the death of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini in June 1989. Rafsanjani has been engaged in efforts to sideline Khomeini's hard-line, anti-Western followers, and rebuild relations with the West to attract investment and advanced technology. The radicals accuse Rafsanjani, and Khamenei, his political ally, of straying from Khomeini's anti-Western legacy. Both leaders deny that this is true. Rafsanjani said in speech to students from around the country Sunday that ``with the capture of the American nest of spies, documents revealing American plots against the revolution were divulged.'' Blaming the United States for pushing Iraq into the 1980-88 war against Iran, he added that ``after the failure of its plots, America imposed the war on Iran.'' The Iranians have condemned Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, but they have also denounced the presence of the U.S.-dominated multinational force in the gulf. Karrubi said in parliament earlier Sunday that Iraq's invasion of Kuwait ``is not the issue. What should come to everyone's attention is that America has come to the region for oil, hegemony and more importantly, to cofront the Islamic revolution and the Moslem forces of the region.'' The date of the embassy takeover also coincides with the day in 1963 that Khomeini was sent into exile by Iranian monarch Shah Mohammed Reza Pahlavi. Khomeini returned in February 1979, overthrew the monarchy, and established the Islamic Republic. On Nov. 4, 1979, Khomeini's militant followers stormed the U.S. Embassy in Tehran and took 52 Americans hostage for 444 days.

DOC.HEAD: Those Last-Minute Shockers: Some Help, Some Don't
DOC.TEXT: October was the cruelest month for many an office-seeker. An illegitimate child, a guru, a long-ago pool party. Events long past surfaced in the late stages of Campaign '90 to haunt candidates and, in at least one case, spell the end of a political career. Minnesota Republican Jon Grunseth suffered a series of seismic shocks that forced him to withdraw from the governor's race. First, two young women accused him of asking them to swim nude with him at a pool party in 1981, when they were teen-agers. Then, another woman said she'd had an affair with him that lasted nearly a decade, through both of his marriages. No one else has been forced out of a race over a character issue. But candidates have been lobbing that type of ammunition with regularity, hoping something will explode. In Texas, allegations suddenly surfaced that Democratic gubernatorial candidate Ann Richards had been seen using cocaine 13 years ago outside a Dallas bar. The charges by a former aide to the man Richards defeated in the Democratic primary were aired in a newspaper article and by a Republican sheriff. A consultant for Clayton Williams, the GOP candidate for governor, said the incident came ``totally out of left field.'' But Richards insisted Williams was behind it. ``This stinks to high heaven,'' she said. ``The story and the actions of the Republican sheriff of Bexar County have taken the Clayton Williams smear campaign to new lows.'' In New Orleans, congressional candidate Marc Morial is trying to control damage from the recent disclosure that he fathered an illegitimate child eight years ago while a law student. The news broke right after the Oct. 6 primary, a few days after the little girl's mother filed suit seeking child support. The woman, now an attorney in Africa, said she had never before sought or received a penny from Morial. Former Rep. Toby Moffett, attempting to recapture a House seat in Connecticut, used his closing time in a debate to unleash an attack against Waterbury alderman Gary Franks, his Republican rival. Moffett said Franks, a landlord, had been cited 51 times for health, fire or safety code violations - including a rat bite. Franks had no time left and could not respond. But after the debate he called Moffett ``Mr. Cheap Shot.'' And in North Carolina, GOP Sen. Jesse Helms is accusing Democrat Harvey Gantt, who is black, of using government for personal gain. The specific charge: getting a cheap television license as part of a minority controlled investment group, then selling the license for a huge profit a few months later. ``It made Mr. Gantt a millionaire,'' Helms said. ``No wonder he has a swimming pool in his back yard and a tennis court. He made that off of a deception.'' Gantt, who has a tennis court but not a swimming pool, said the minority investors sold their license because operating the station was going to cost far more than expected. He said voters should be contemplating education and the environment - ``not whether or not I bought a television station with private money.'' In Oregon, Sen. Mark Hatfield ignored Democratic challenger Harry Lonsdale until it looked like Lonsdale might unseat him. Then state Republicans revived a 5-year-old controversy over Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh - an Indian guru who died in the interim. A county judge who was poisoned by the guru's followers five years ago held a news conference to release copies of a newspaper ad signed and paid for by Lonsdale. The ad ran shortly after Rajneesh pleaded guilty to immigration fraud charges and left the country. It said Americans should be ashamed of ``the harassment and abuse heaped on this gentle man.'' Lonsdale said last week that the guru's followers were persecuted because they were different. He said his ad was meant to support religious freedom and that Hatfield had written Rajneesh a letter reflecting the same sentiments. Some campaign surprises fizzled or backfired immediately on impact. In Connecticut, GOP Rep. John Rowland accused former Sen. Lowell Weicker, a rival for the governor's seat, of violating a Senate conflict-of-interest rule and possibly engaging in insider trading of stocks and bonds. Weicker was ready. ``The entire premise of Mr. Rowland's smear rests on a nonexistent Senate rule and a web of circumstance and innuendo,'' he declared. Running as an independent, Weicker still leads the three-way race. Across the country in Nebraska, former Sen. John Tower said he'd heard that Democratic Sen. Jim Exon was a boozer. Tower's remark, made during a campaign appearance for Exon's rival, former Rep. Hal Daub, sparked a round of speculation on Exon's drinking habits. But Tower may have done Daub more harm than good in his quest to unseat Exon. The remark prompted a revival of rumors that Daub abused his wife, and it caused her to release a letter saying the allegations weren't true. Cindy Daub said Exon ``implied that my husband beat me up which resulted in me going to so-called shelters.'' She called that ``the most heinous personal attack possible and unbecoming of a United States senator.'' Exon is coasting to an easy win.

DOC.HEAD: Councilman: Tacoma Shouldn't Have Given Up Cobblestones
DOC.TEXT: City employees who sold thousands of cobblestones taken from a driveway near the historic Union Station might have made a costly mistake, says a city councilman. Councilman Bob Evans says he and members of the Landmarks Preservation Commission discovered that about 24,000 cobblestones were sold to a contractor who gave the city $1,000 in credit toward other work on the station-restoration project. ``In my view, we gave away a very valuable resource for nothing,'' said Evans, an architect. City public-works officials should have known about a design guideline that requires historic materials salvaged from the station be saved for other city projects, he said last week. No one has come up with an estimate of the stones' worth, said City Engineer Ben Thompson. Union Station is being renovated and a wing added to house federal courts. Public-works officials say they were simply trying to save money with the cobblestone arrangement.

DOC.HEAD: Klansmen Outnumbered 10-to-1 By Police During March
DOC.TEXT: Some three dozen Christian Knights of the Ku Klux Klan marched under the watchful eye of more than 10 times as many police officers. Saturday's march marked the 11th anniversary of the shooting deaths of five Communist Workers Party members by Klansmen and Nazis. There were a few taunts exchanged Saturday, but no violence, officials said. About 350 police officers surrounded the 34 Klansmen while they marched to the Phill G. McDonald Plaza. The rally attracted about 200 spectators - most opposed to the Klan. The crowd's chant of ``Go Home,'' and ``End Racism'' often drowned out the bullhorn messages from Klansmen. As they marched, the Klansmen sang, ``Who are we? KKK. What do we want? White rights in America. When do we want them? Now.'' On Nov. 3, 1979, a confrontation between Klansmen, Nazis and Communist Workers Party in Greensboro led to five deaths and criticism that Greensboro police failed to adequately monitor the event and prepare for possible trouble.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Governors In Jeopardy In Tuesday's Elections
With AM-Election Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: At least six Republican governors are in danger of losing their jobs in Tuesday's elections as they are judged by voters frustrated by higher taxes and worried about recession. GOP control of several open seats also is in jeopardy. And the races for five of the biggest states - California, Texas, Florida, Ohio and Illinois - are closely contested. Four of the five, Ohio being the exception, are in GOP hands now. ``Republicans are hanging on by a thread in almost a dozen races,'' said political analyst Charles Cook. ``Many more Republican seats are closer to the edge than Democratic ones.'' High on the list of vulnerable GOP governors is Florida Gov. Bob Martinez, who is locked in a close race with Democratic challenger Lawton Chiles. GOP governors in Nebraska, Kansas, Maine and Rhode Island also are trailing or in close contests in the polls. A sixth, Alabama Gov. Guy Hunt, is in a close race in a state that hadn't elected a GOP governor this century until he won four years ago. Hunt faces Democrat Paul Hubbert in what has become a bitter contest. GOP Govs. Kay Orr in Nebraska and Mike Hayden in Kansas started behind due to voter anger over local tax increases. Incumbents Edward DiPrete in Rhode Island and John McKernan in Maine were hurt by the Northeast's economic downturn. McKernan has staged a comeback in the polls against former Gov. Joseph Brennan. But there's been no recovery for DiPrete - polls show him down as much as 3-to-1 to Democrat Bruce Sundlun. Republican retirements also have left Democrats in strong positions in New Mexico and Oklahoma. Some Democratic-controlled governorships may fall too, however. And with a 29-21 advantage in governor's seats, Democrats have more to lose in the 36 gubernatorial races this year. Many races were statistical dead heats in the final days before the election. ``It could be the best of times; it could be the worst of times,'' said Mark Gearan, director of the Democratic Governors' Association. ``We could be in a situation where all of our candidates win, or they don't. But it's also clear in several of the open seats we have leads right now.'' At least two potential Democratic losses may not be GOP gains. Independent candidates are leading in three-way races in Alaska and Connecticut. Both independent candidates are former Republicans now running outside their party: former Nixon cabinet member Wally Hickel in Alaska and former Sen. Lowell Weicker in Connecticut. Among Democratic incumbents, Minnesota Gov. Rudy Perpich is in danger despite Republican turmoil. GOP nominee Jon Grunseth withdrew last week because of a sexual impropriety scandal and was replaced by Arne Carlson, who was strongly opposed by anti-abortion conservatives. For all the Republican woes, polls showed Carlson in a tight race with Perpich, a two-term incumbent known for his eccentricity. Democrats are in danger of losing Ohio. Republican George Voinovich, the former mayor of Cleveland, is leading Democrat Anthony Celebrezze, who made a celebrated switch to support for abortion rights. Democratic Gov. Richard Celeste is retiring. Seeking a third term in Michigan, Democrat James Blanchard is in a race that has tightened in recent days. A late poll showed Republican John Engler pulling to within 4 percentage points. But a combination of economic recession, the abortion issue and a variety of regional distinctions appears to give Democrats the upper hand in many of the governor's races. ``Close to an unmitigated disaster,'' was how conservative political consultant David Keene summarized GOP prospects. ``The only hope we have is the volatility.'' Republican attention has focused on the biggest states, where the party hopes to hold veto power when Democratic legislatures draw new congressional maps to reflect results of the 1990 Census. California is the biggest prize, with a potential seven-seat House gain. Democrat Dianne Feinstein is in a close race against GOP Sen. Pete Wilson, though some polls give Wilson the edge. ``California - that's the ball game,'' said Norm Cummings, political director of the Republican National Committee. In Florida, Martinez has recovered from a double-digit deficit in the polls but still faces high negative ratings left from a tax flip-flop early in his term and anger over his anti-abortion moves. Chiles has his own troubles, too, however, including controversy over his acknowledged use of an anti-depression drug.
