The National Abortion Rights Action League has been airing anti-Martinez commercials, though Chiles appears reluctant to push the issue much himself. Another headline race is in Texas, where Republican Clayton Williams has squandered a big lead through a series of gaffes, including his refusal to shake hands with Democrat Ann Richards. Williams, who has put some $8 million of his own money into the race, has built a following by campaigning as a rough-hewn Texas cowboy. His string of missteps continued into the final weekend of the campaign, when he admitted in an offhand way that he paid no income taxes for 1986. Polls showed the race a tossup.

DOC.HEAD: Hindus Call End to Mosque Dispute
DOC.TEXT: Hindu leaders on Sunday suspended a campaign to seize a mosque after claiming to reach an accord with authorities, but officials said no concessions were made to end the dispute that has left at least 325 dead. In New Delhi, meanwhile, moves to oust Prime Minister V.P. Singh grew while opponents worked for compromises to prevent new Parliament elections. Despite the signs of calm in Ayodhya, about 300 miles southeast of New Delhi, violence linked to the mosque flared in neighboring nations. At least two Moslems were killed by a Hindu mob in Nepal, and security around Hindu temples in Pakistan was increased to prevent Moslem attacks. The Hindu militants said they reached a deal with civil authorities to allow them to visit the disputed holy site on Wednesday. Ashok Singhal, who was at the forefront of the Hindu assault on the mosque last week, called on thousands of pilgrims in Ayodhya to end the seige and hold a traditional Hindu fire ceremony to mark the end of a significant event. Singhal said a prayer meeting would start Monday and conclude Wednesday with a visit to the 460-year-old mosque, which they claim was built atop the birthplace of the Hindu warrior god Rama. But authorities said they had not yet decided to lift a curfew on Ayodhya that would let the prayer meeting go ahead. Hindus seek to raze the mosque and erect a Hindu temple on the site. A handwritten statement from Singhal, leader of the World Hindu Council, said a public meeting would be held Nov. 11 in New Delhi to decide the future campaign for the temple project. Sources said the fundamentalists had presented four demands for ending the standoff. Among the requests is the lifting of a 10-day-old curfew in Ayodhya, allowing Hindu worshipers to visit the disputed shrine, and the release of Hindus arrested while attempting to start construction of the temple. But sources indicated Hindu leaders were prepared to drop a demand for the suspension of officers who ordered police toopen fire on rampaging mobs Tuesday and Friday. At least 22 people were killed in the two incidents, among at least 325 killed nationwide in the dispute. About 4,000 Hindus from across the country have left Ayodhya in the past few days, ignoring pleas from their leaders to stay until the temple is built. An estimated 10,000 remain. The dispute was touched off when the leader of a Hindu right-wing party, Lal Krishna Advani, was arrested Oct. 24 while leading a caravan to Ayodhya to help build the proposed temple. Since the arrest, riots have spread across India and neighboring nations. It has also brought Singh's 11-month-old coalition government to the brink of collapse. Singh, who faces a confidence vote Wednesday, lost his majority in Parliament when the pro-Hindu Bharatiya Janata Party withdrew support because of the Ayodhya dispute. Hindus make up 82 percent of India's 880 million people, while Moslems comprise 12 percent. On Sunday, two ministers resigned from the government, raising to five the number in the 38-member Cabinet who deserted Singh in the last two weeks. Meanwhile, two Singh opponents in his Janata Dal Party said they plan a meeting Monday with other dissident party members. They hope to dump Singh as party leader and prime minister in hopes of preserving the government and averting parliamentary elections. But Advani, who was released Sunday, said new elections were the only way out of the political impasse. ``This government has forfeited both its moral and political right to continue even for a single day,'' he said. In Nepal, two Moslems who allegedly defiled a Hindu temple were killed Saturday when Hindus stormed a house where they were being held to await authorities. Five people were injured in the incident in Harion, about 50 miles south of Katmandu, the Home Ministry said. Moslems comprise only 3 percent of Nepal's 16 million people. Ninety percent are Hindu. In mainly Moslem Pakistan, police and army troops increased patrols around Hindu temples Sunday after several attacks, including an attempt Saturday to blow up a temple in the southern port city of Karachi, newspaper reports said.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Actor Marlon Brando's daughter has returned to consciousness from a coma caused by a drug overdose, which her father insists was not a suicide attempt. A Brando family spokesman, who demanded anonymity, said Cheyenne Brando came out of the coma Saturday but was suffering serious stomach disorders from the tranquilizers and anti-depressants she ingested Thursday. Brando may fly to the island from Los Angeles in the next few days, depending on the status of the murder trial of Cheyenne's half-brother, Christian Brando. Christian Brando, 32, is charged with murder in the shooting death of Miss Brando's Tahitian lover, Dag Drollet. He was scheduled to go on trial Monday, but jury selection has been delayed. Miss Brando left the United States a month after Drollet was slain and gave birth to their child in Tahiti. She refused to return to testify and was accused by French authorities in Tahiti of being an accessory to the murder. The French weekly newspaper Le Journal du Dimanche quoted the 66-year-old actor in its Sunday editions as saying his daughter did not intend to kill herself with the drug overdose. ``She absorbed too much medicine that she was was given by her doctors. That's all,'' he said. --- RENO, Nev. (AP) - Comedian Rich Little tailored his act to fit his audience while visiting young hospital patients. Instead of doing his trademark impressions of Richard Nixon, Ronald Reagan and George Bush, Little did Kermit the Frog and the Cookie Monster. Little, who's appearing at Harrah's Reno, said he had to change his act at Washoe Medical Center because many young people have not heard of him or the people he's famous for imitating. ``The kids don't know who I am,'' he said Friday. ``The nurses will be falling about and the kids are looking at me like I should be locked up in a bed somewhere.'' --- NEW YORK (AP) - Salman Rushdie says that during his 21 months in hiding from Moslem fundamentalists he's resumed smoking, become addicted to the telephone and misses little things one takes for granted - like shopping. ``It is not that I ever was a big shopper,'' the author said in an interview in Sunday's issue of The New York Times Magazine. ``But when you cannot shop, you come to understand better the pleasure it affords.'' Rushdie, 43, has been hiding in dozens of different safe houses in England since February 1989, when Iran put a death sentence on him for his novel ``The Satanic Verses.'' Some Moslems found the book's depiction of Islam offensive. Since going into hiding, his marriage to novelist Marianne Wiggins has fallen apart. He can make calls but can't receive them, says he watches too much television and has reread many of his favorite novels. --- NASHVILLE, Tenn. (AP) - Some of country music's top stars gathered on stage at the Grand Ole Opry for a tribute to humorist Minnie Pearl on her 50th anniversary with the show. Others sent recorded tributes to be shown during Saturday's show, including one from Dolly Parton, who said: ``I love you. I miss you.'' To which Miss Pearl responded: ``I wear a hat so folks can tell us apart.'' Miss Pearl, 78, wearing her trademark gingham dress and straw hat with its $1.98 price tag dangling, greeted the Opry crowd and the live Nashville Network cable television audience with her standard salutation: ``How-deee! I'm just so glad to be here!'' ``This is a special night for all of us,'' said Roy Acuff, 87, who has performed with Pearl throughout her career. --- CHICAGO (AP) - The actor who played the youngest member of the spooky family portrayed on the 1960s television series ``The Munsters'' is out on bail after a dispute over a limousine driver's services. Patrick Allan Lilley, known as Butch Patrick when he played Eddie Munster during 1964-66, was arrested Friday on a charge of stealing $130 from the driver, police said. Police said Lilley, 37, of Austin, Texas, was a passenger with another man in the limousine. ``Lilley contends that the driver was less than cordial and he kept getting them lost,'' said Nicholas Kerkeles, who defended Lilley at his arraignment. ``A fight began and Munster, er, Mr. Lilley, apparently took the wallet, claiming that the driver shouldn't have been paid in the first place.'' Lilley was released on $1,000 bail. He told a judge he makes a living attending conventions and making personal appearances as his television character.

DOC.HEAD: Council of Europe Adding East European Members
DOC.TEXT: Hungary plans to join the Council of Europe on Tuesday, the first of several former Communist bloc nations expected to gain membership in the oldest postwar body promoting European cooperation. Hungary will seal its membership by signing the council's human rights treaty at a ceremony in Rome. The 1950 treaty established the European Court of Human Rights, which has heard more than 15,000 such cases from the 23 present council members. The rights treaty is one of 130 international conventions - ranging from computer data protection to anti-terrorism measures - that Council of Europe nations have signed to date. Other East European nations are expected to gain admittance next year as the 41-year-old council expands its role with Europe emerging from the Cold War. Czechoslovakia, Poland, the Soviet Union and Yugoslavia have been given observer status as a step toward full membership. Romania and Albania may become observers soon, officials said. For membership, a country must be a pluralistic democracy and must sign the human rights convention. The Strasbourg-based council has long existed in the shadow of other organizations, notably the more powerful European Community, a separate 12-nation body based in Brussels, Belgium. But the council is now seeking to become the primary body bringing together nations from both sides of the former Iron Curtain. ``The countries of Eastern Europe urgently need a structure capable of accommodating them and assisting them on the path to democratic reform,'' said Catherine Lalumiere, the council's secretary general. The Council of Europe wants to form a 300-seat assembly of legislators from among the 34 European and North American nations in the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, and become Europe's chief human rights watchdog. In both cases, the council would take on activities of the CSCE, a loosely defined body established in 1975 as a forum for occasional talks between former Cold War adversaries, especially on human rights and security issues. The conference includes the United States, Canada and all of Europe except Albania. Many European governments now believe the conference must be strengthened and see the Council of Europe as the right organization for the job. ``It would be both logical and reasonable for the Council of Europe to be given a mandate by the CSCE to continue that conference's work by implementing the principles which it has laid down,'' Ms. Lalumiere said. Only the United States has raised objections to the plan. But the other conference members may decide to push for a parliamentary assembly without immediate U.S. participation, said Anders Bjorck of Sweden, president of the Council's Parliamentary Assembly. ``The U.S. position is causing widespread irritation to say the least,'' Bjorck said. ``But we will not change our position.'' A conference summit is scheduled for Nov. 19-21 in Paris. The meeting is expected to be highlighted by the signing of a NATO-Warsaw Pact accord ordering deep cuts in conventional forces from the Atlantic Ocean to the Ural Mountains.

DOC.HEAD: Parents' Persistence Leads to Arrests in Son's Hunting Death
DOC.TEXT: A blast from a hunter's shotgun killed his son two years ago, but when no one came forward to accept responsibility, Martin C. Rogan knew what had to be done. ``My son was the type of kid who would have said to me: `Find out who killed me and don't let this go,''' said Rogan, his eyes filling with tears. ``I felt an extreme responsibility to learn what happened,'' he said. Jack C. Rogan was found dead in the woods a few hundred yards behind his rural eastern Connecticut home on Nov. 25, 1988, the second day of the deer hunting season. A single pellet of buckshot had struck the 26-year-old in the neck and penetrated the lower part of his brain, an autopsy showed. Tormented by the unanswered questions about their son's death, and embittered by the belief that a hunter knew of his deadly mistake but didn't want to fess up, Martin and Betty Rogan doggedly pursued the case. They offered a $15,000 reward, hired a private investigator, wrote to political leaders, unsuccessfully sought a grand jury investigation, and finally took a suspect to court in a civil case. The man, a neighbor of Jack Rogan's, refused to respond to more than 100 questions, asserting his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination. The Rogans' persistence paid off. Two men were arrested in October, including the neighbor, after state police detectives followed up a tip the Rogans received in August from an anonymous telephone caller. Only 10 days before Jack Rogan's death, a woman in Maine, Karen Wood, was killed by a hunter in an accident that focused national attention on the dangers that each hunting season brings. The Rogans became good friends with Wood's husband, Kevin Wood, and attended the manslaughter trial last month of the man who shot his wife. The trial ended with an acquittal. ``He could understand our feelings and we could understand his,'' Rogan said. The dangers of hunting season was brought home in Pennsylvania when that state's small-game season opened late last month. Three hunters were fatally shot during turkey-hunting accidents on opening day alone. ``Unfortunately, the key to these accidents is that people are not positively identifying their targets,'' said Jim Filkosky, who is in charge of hunter education for the Pennsylvania Game Commission. In the Rogan case, police allege a young man hunting illegally shot Jack Rogan and fled before police arrived, letting his hunting companion cover up for him. Michael Wisniewski Jr., 23, was charged with first-degree manslaughter. Police said he did not have a hunting license, was using buckshot, which is illegal in Connecticut, and fired the fatal shot after the close of the legal shooting time. Richard P. Gorman, 41, who lives two houses down the road from the Rogan house, was arrested on a charge of hindering prosecution. Police contend that Wisniewski mistook Rogan for a deer and shot him and that Gorman made up a story to protect him. Gorman, who is married to Wisniewski's cousin, told police he was hunting alone just before sunset when he heard shots and discovered the body. Both Wisniewski and Gorman plan to plead innocent to the charges, their lawyers said. Jack Rogan, the owner of his own trucking and excavation business, was not hunting when he was shot. A hammer and nails were found by his side. His father said he wasn't sure what his son was doing. ``We will not be satisfied until justice has come a complete path, someone is convicted and we get all the details of what went on,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Small Rally Marks Anniversary of East Germany's Biggest Protest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th pvs, `Look for...' to CORRECT dollar figure; Pickup 10th, `Baerbel Bohley...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-After the Wall
DOC.TEXT: The people who orchestrated the biggest protest in East Germany's Communist history marked the occasion Sunday with a small rally against a united Germany's capitalist system. About 5,000 people met on Alexanderplatz, Berlin's central square and the scene of a historic rally that drew an estimated 1 million people one year earlier. The Nov. 4, 1989, rally helped lead to the opening of the Berlin Wall five days later, sped the pace of democratic reforms and was a key link in the chain of events that resulted in German unity. The demonstrators on Sunday demanded better social guarantees as the former East German nation, which joined West Germany on Oct. 3, struggles to adapt to a free market democracy. Unemployment and living costs have skyrocketed in the last few months. The old socialist system, which guaranteed low prices and full employment while denying basic freedoms of speech and travel, is being dismantled. One year ago, Alexanderplatz was a spine-tingling sea of people who stood peacefully on the sprawling plaza and chanted ``We are the people!'' at a shocked, disoriented Communist leadership on the brink of extinction. The chant later evolved into ``We are one people'' as the revolt for freedom was supplanted by a mass movement for German unity. On Sunday, protesters held up signs saying ``We are a stupid people,'' and ``We were the people'' to protest what they say is a coldly pragmatic capitalist system that pays insufficient attention to the human costs of the nation's radical economic and social transition. ``Look for a job as a minister without portfolio,'' read one sign, a jab at the five former East German government officials who now make more than $2,800 monthly as ministers in the united government. The ministers have no clearly defined duties. Baerbel Bohley, leader of the New Forum activist group and the best known of the dissidents who helped lead the democratic revolt, was among several famous people at Sunday's rally. ``The revolution is not over, and therefore we may not stand aside,'' she told the crowd. New Forum, an association of liberal artists and intellectuals, was unable to establish a clearly defined political identity after its remarkable success with the peaceful democracy revolution. Despite acting as the voice of the people during the former nation's most dramatic period of crisis, New Forum and its affiliated groups have been reduced to a respected but largely unsupported fringe political party. Several celebrities attended Sunday's rally, including British actress Glenda Jackson, American folksinger Pete Seeger, and German authors Christa Wolf and Guenter Grass.

DOC.HEAD: Reagan Says He Didn't Have to Think 30 Seconds About Selling Arms to Iran
DOC.TEXT: Former President Reagan says he ``didn't have to think 30 seconds'' about selling missiles to Iran, but denies he tried to swap weapons for American hostages, according to excerpts of his memoirs published Sunday. Reagan also acknowleged he still doesn't know all the facts in the Iran-Contra case, which became the biggest scandal of his eight-year administration. In the case, weapons were sold to Iran with the profits secretly diverted to the Nicaraguan Contra rebels. While the Iran-Contra case made him unhappy, Reagan said his greatest regret as president was sending Marines to Beirut, Lebanon where a suicide bomber attacked the Marine barracks on Oct. 23, 1983, killing 241 servicemen. Reagan said he was convinced it was a good idea to deploy Marines in war-torn Lebanon as peace-keepers. But American officials did not realize how vulnerable the servicemen were in the barracks on a wide-open space. ``In any case, sending the Marines to Beirut was the source of my greatest regret and greatest sorrow,'' Reagan wrote in the excerpts from ``An American Life'' appearing in the this week's editions of Time magazine. On the Iran-Contra case, Reagan said he and other officials relied heavily on information from Israeli officials in deciding to sell weapons to Iran in mid-1985. At first Reagan said he didn't want to do it because the Iranians sponsored terrorism. But the former president said when he learned through the Israelis that the group seeking the weapons did not support terrorist activities, he didn't hesitate. ``Once we had information that we could trust the people in Iran, I didn't have to think 30 seconds about saying yes. I was told the few missiles would not significantly change the balance in Iran's war with Iraq so I said, O.K., one small shipment from Israel to allow the Israelis to prove they were talking with the highest levels of the U.S. government.'' But Reagan said he insisted the Iranians use their influence to get American hostages in Lebanon freed. The hostages were held by pro-Iranian Shiites Moslems. Over a 15-month period, three American hostages were released, but three more were captured. Six Americans remain in captivity in Lebanon. Terry Anderson, a correspondent for The Associated Press who was seized in March 1985, is the longest held American. ``No problem was more frustrating for me than trying to get the hostages home,'' Reagan said. Even so, he denied that the weapons sale was a arms-for-hostages deal. ``To this day, I still believe that the Iran initiative was not an effort to swap arms for hostages. But I know it may not look that way to some people,'' he wrote. Nevertheless, Reagan said the ``cloud that descended over my credibility during Iran-Contra undoubtedly affected my last two years in office.'' Even today, Reagan said he is in the dark about some details. A presidential commission and an independent counsel have both investigated the case. If he could re-live the past, Reagan said he would demand that former national security adviser John Poindexter and his then-aide, Oliver North, explain Iran-Contra. They were most involved in setting up the diversion. ``I would bring both of them into the Oval Office and say, `O.K. John and Ollie, level with me. Tell me what really happened and what it is that you have been hiding from me. Tell me everything,''' Reagan wrote. ``If I had done that, at least I wouldn't be sitting here, writing this book, still ignorant of some of the things that went on during the Iran-Contra affair,'' he wrote.

DOC.HEAD: First-time Offender Fights Life Sentence on Drug Charge
DOC.TEXT: Ronald Harmelin didn't fit the flashy drug kingpin image - no tailored silk suit, dripping gold jewelry or gleaming Mercedes-Benz for him. Still, he had 672 grams of cocaine in the trunk of his 9-year-old Ford when he was arrested by suburban Oak Park police on May 12, 1986. Under Michigan law, that was enough to justify his life sentence without parole. The U.S. Supreme Court is scheduled to hear arguments Monday on whether Michigan's law requiring such a sentence is cruel and unusual punishment. Under the state's law, possession of 650 grams or more of cocaine brings a mandatory sentence of life in prison without parole. Harmelin probably would be out of prison by now if federal officials arrested him. Under federal law, a first offender possessing 650 grams - almost 1{ pounds - would face a five-to-40-year penalty with possibility of parole. ``That's the difference between being busted by the Drug Enforcement Administration and Oak Park police. It's the difference between one year and the rest of his life,'' said Paul Denenfeld, a lawyer for the American Civil Liberties Union. ``It flies in the face of individualized sentencing.'' From his cell at Scott Regional Facility in a Detroit suburb, the 45-year-old Harmelin got the high court's attention with a petition that he was ``unjustly thrown into the pit of prison for all eternity without the hope of release.'' That's the point, said Oakland County prosecutor Richard Thompson, who will argue that Harmelin's sentence is constitutional. ``Michigan's law is the most enlightened in the country,'' Thompson said. ``It provides a deterrent and permanently removes the drug trafficking from the community.'' Detroit lawyer Carla Johnson, appointed to represent Harmelin, said sentencing should look at prior criminal record and level of involvement in the drug world. Harmelin had no prior record. ``He was not proven to be anything but a possessor of cocaine,'' Johnson said. ``The people who end up doing mandatory life are not the kingpins the statute was aimed at. These people are mostly first-time offenders and to punish them like we punish murderers is not right.'' The ACLU said it was concerned other states will enact laws similar to Michigan's if it is upheld by the Supreme Court. In California, for instance, no state laws regulate sentencing for drug crimes. Judges rely on federal guidelines to put away drug dealers for life without parole. ``We'll certainly be taking a look at the Michigan case,'' said John Gordnier, an assistant attorney general in California. ``We'll be interested in the arguments.'' Gordnier said the concept of life without parole is appropriate. ``Many of those who deal with narcotics have probably caused someone to receive drugs and later die as a result of the drugs,'' he said. ``The penalty is not inappropriate given the price society is paying.'' In Florida, those convicted of selling, purchasing or delivering more than 400 grams of cocaine face a mandatory 15 years in prison and a $250,000 fine, said Richard Doran, the Florida attorney general's director of criminal appeals. Florida doesn't have to prove the offender was a dealer. ``If you have more than 400 grams in your possession, the state assumes you're a trafficker,'' Doran said. Cocaine is usually sold by the gram. Neil Fink, chairman of Criminal Defense Lawyers of Michigan, said if the high court upholds the law, Harmelin can again petition the Michigan Supreme Court, which refused in January to hear the case. There are 123 inmates in Michigan serving sentences like Harmelin's. Harmelin, who could not be interviewed, can only wait. A decision is expected early next year. Johnson said Harmelin remains hopeful. ``With all this publicity, he's kind of got his spirits up a little bit,'' Johnson said. ``Freedom is a state of mind. If you think you can get out, there's some hope and you can tolerate it.''

DOC.HEAD: Franciszek Szlachcic, Former Polish Interior Minister, Dead at 70
DOC.TEXT: Maj. Gen. Franciszek Szlachcic, a former interior minister and member of the Communist Party Politburo, has died, the official PAP news agency reported Sunday. He was 70. PAP said Szlachcic died Saturday but did not say what the cause was or where it occurred. Szlachcic, a member of the Communist People's Army during the Nazi occupation, joined the Soviet-backed Communists as they consolidated power in Poland following World War II. He joined the Communist Party when it was founded in 1948 and rose through the ranks, reaching the Politburo during the early 1970s. He was interior minister in 1971 and deputy chairman of the Council of Ministers until hisrretirement in 1976. In recent years, he served as president of the Polish Committee for Standardization, Measures and Quality Control, and joined other former members of the Communist leadership in writing memoirs. The Communist Party was dissolved in January, following the transfer of power to a government lead by the independent, non-Communist Solidarity movement.

DOC.HEAD: Abul Abbas Confirms Libya Closed His Camps
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 20-21 pvs, `Abbas denied ...' with one graf to ADD that Genoa court convicted Abbas in absentia of masterminding the Achille Lauro hijacking. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Abul Abbas, the mastermind of the Achille Lauro ship hijacking five years ago, confirmed Sunday that Libya has expelled 145 members of his radical group and closed down four training camps. Abul Abbas said the move was a surprise to him and his wing of the Palestine Liberation Front, considered to be a major terrorist organization. He said the ejection was unjustified and urged Libya's leader, Col. Moammar Gadhafi, to reopen the camps and the group's offices. The government in Tripoli has not given an explanation for its action, he said. Reports began to surface about a week ago that Libya had expelled the Palestinians. Arab diplomats in Baghdad said the United States had asked King Hassan of Morroco and Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak to press Gadhafi to eject the group. Gadhafi is believed to want Libya's removal from the U.S. State Department's list of countries supporting terrorism. PLO chief Yasser Arafat has also been pressed to dissociate himself from Abul Abbas, who has one seat on the executive committee of the Palestine Liberation Organization. Pressure to remove Abul Abbas increased after his group raided an Israeli beach in May, an action that to a break in U.S.-PLO dialogue. After the raid on the Israeli beach, Abul Abbas apologized to Arafat, saying the PLO chief did not about the raid in advance. He also said that civilians were not targets in that raid, counter to Israeli claims. Abul Abbas dismissed reports the PLO leadership had asked Libya to kick out his group. ``We rule out any possibility that the PLO leadership has asked for this, but some Palestinian circles who oppose our militant line might have done so,'' he said. He said that most of the group had moved to Lebanon, and others to places that he delined to name. Abul Abbas, whose real name is Mohammed Abbas, leads one of two wings of the Palestine front, which split from Ahmed Jibril's Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command in 1977. Based in Baghdad since leaving Lebanon in 1982, Abul Abbas is believed to have several hundred guerrilla fighters in his organization - in Iraq, Lebanon and, until now, Libya. The other wing of the Palestine front, based in Damascus, was led by Talaat Yacoub, who died two years ago. Abul Abbas said two of the camps were places where PLO fighters were trained for ``naval combat.'' One was a small town east of Tripoli and the other was west of Tripoli, he said. He did not provide the others' locations. The Palestinian leader said his group would continue its ``armed struggle'' against Israel but insisted that the group will not attack any targets outside of the Jewish state. Abul Abbas said that he had no plans to attack Americans or other Westerners despite the Persian Gulf crisis. But he said his group will fight alongside Iraq if it is attacked by the U.S.-led multinational forces in the Gulf. ``In pan-Arab battles we will carry out our duties alongside our brothers in Iraq,'' he said. The Achille Lauro, a Mediterranean cruise ship, was hijacked Oct. 7, 1985 and held by terrorists for two days. A 69-year-old wheelchair-bound Jewish-American passenger, Leon Klinghoffer, was killed during the hijacking and his body dumped into the sea. A Genoa court in 1986 convicted Abbas in absentia of masterminding the hijacking. Abbas maintained had merely played a role in negotiating the release of the ship in exchange for freedom for the hijackers.

DOC.HEAD: Sikh Militants Line Up and Shoot 20 Passersby
DOC.TEXT: Sikh separatists stopped passing motorists and cyclists near a village in Punjab state Sunday, lined them up on the roadside and shot them, news agencies reported. The Press Trust of India said at least 17 people were killed, including a police constable. Another domestic news agency, United News of India, said 20 people were killed in the incident in the district of Gurdaspur. Also Sunday in Punjab, a bomb exploded at the gate of a movie theater in the small town of Pathankot, injuring 14 people, United News reported. The agency said 21 people, including four security personnel and two Sikh militants, were killed in other incidents around Punjab state Sunday, or their bodies were found. More than 2,600 people have been reported killed so far this year by Sikh militants hoping to establish an independent state in Punjab, a wealthy farming region bordering Pakistan. Military officials have said the independence movement is also being used as a cover for extortionists and thieves. In one incident Sunday, three Sikh militants broke into a home in a village demanding money for the separatist cause. One militant was caught and beaten to death, while the others escaped, the news agencies reported. A second militant was killed in a shootout with police Sunday, and the bodies of two Sikhs who had apparently been shot by rival groups were discovered, the agencies said. Last month, the Indian government decided to extend federal rule over Punjab for another six months, arguing the situation precluded holding elections for state government. The previous government was dismissed in 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Rejects U.N. Proposal for Increased Arab Protection
DOC.TEXT: Troops wounded dozens of Palestinians Sunday and ordered curfews across the Gaza Strip. Government leaders dismissed as ``one-sided'' a U.N. call for international protection of Arabs under Israeli occupation. Israel radio said 86 Palestinians were injured in widespread clashes following the death of a jailed Palestinian, while Arab reports said 70 were hurt. The army put the number at 27 and said it was checking the other figures. A Foreign Ministry statement castigated U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar for his report Thursday in which he suggested broadening the mandate of U.N. institutions in Israel to safeguard the 1.7 million Palestinians under occupation. The report was produced as a recommendation to the U.N. Security Council on response to the killing Oct. 8 of 20 Palestinians on Jersusalem's Temple Mount by Israeli authorities. ``The world community's continued preoccupation with this subject can only serve those forces who are interested in creating a link between the Arab-Israeli conflict and the gulf crisis,'' the statement said. The statement assailed a proposal to convene the signatories of the Fourth Geneva Convention of 1949, which sets out rules for the treatment of civilians in wartime. ``Israel is disappointed at the one-sided approach exhibited in the report,'' it said. ``The recommendations in the report are directed only toward Israel and do not see fit to call for a cessation of violence on the Palestinian side.'' Israel has refused to accept a U.N. investigation into the Oct. 8 incident on Temple Mount, a site holy to both Jews and Moslems. Israel says the inquiry would undermine its sovereignty in Jerusalem. Israel had conducted its own investigation and ``extracted the necessary lessons,'' it said. A government-appointed panel defended the action by police, saying they faced a threat to their lives. But it also said top officers failed to adequately supervise riot-control troops. Under the panel's recommendation, the Cabinet set up a permanent seven-member ministerial committee to oversee Temple Mount affairs. Police Minister Roni Milo upgraded Jerusalem to a full police district Sunday, acting on the commission's recommendations. Milo did not say if senior officers would be transferred or fired. About 350 officers will be added to Jerusalem's 1,000-member force and the public will be encouraged to volunteer for the Civil Guard, said police spokeswoman Ruth Shlezinger. In the Gaza Strip, extensive curfews were imposed and the area of 750,000 residents was declared a military zone and was closed to reporters. Arab reports said at least 180 people were injured during the weekend violence, started with rumors that a Palestinian inmate was killed by Israeli troops. Israeli authorities say the man hanged himself in his cell. In some sections of Gaza City, streets were littered with stones and scorched remains of burning tires. Masked youths in the city's Nasser Quarter fired rocks with slingshots at soldiers checking identification papers on a street. Arsonists gutted the town hall of Khan Yunis in Gaza, Arab reports said. Gaza police were not immediately available for comment. A senior aide of Palestine Liberation Organization chief Yasser Arafat claimed two girls' schools with hundreds of pupils in the Gaza Strip were hit by gas bombs fired by Israeli troops. Bassam Abu Sharif also said in a statement that dozens of other Arabs were wounded when Israeli troops opend fired on a Khan Yunis hospital and a number of clinics in the area run by the U.N. Relief and Works Agency. The statement was sent to The Associated Press in Nicosia, Cyprus, from PLO headquarters in Tunis, Tunisia. Israel captured the West Bank, Gaza Strip and Arab east Jerusalem in the 1967 Middle East war and later annexed east Jerusalem.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Visits Troops in Saudi Desert as He Launches New Gulf Assessment
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1st graf to conform dateline to AP style; SUBS 6th graf pvs, bgng: `I'm from,' to include additional quote about having a baby; SUBS 16th graf pvs, Here he, with 6 grafs to UPDATE with meeting with officials in Bahrain
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III ventured into the desert of Saudi Arabia on Sunday to give a pep talk to 4,200 U.S. troops who may be ordered into combat against Iraq if other pressure tactics do not free Kuwait from Saddam Hussein's grasp. The men and women who must weather dust-storms, searing heat and boredom were mostly receptive to their distinguished visitor, who was launching a fast-paced survey of Arab, European and Soviet sentiment for war with Iraq. One soldier gave Baker a chew of tobacco, another a package of combat rations. Baker, a Texan and ex-Marine, received both offerings comfortably. He chewed the tobacco and said of the food: ``I used to live on this stuff. It was a little bit different then - they were in cans.'' But there were murmurs of discontent within the ranks, as well. ``Most of us assume we will be going to war sooner or later,'' 2nd Lt. Henry Wardick, 23, a West Point graduate, told reporters. ``I'm from Alabama,'' a female sergeant said. ``I'm tired of eating this dirt. I'm tired of drinking hot water. I'm ready to go home.'' Moreover, she said, ``I haven't had a chance to have a baby.'' And when Baker, who wore khakis and worn cowboy boots, told another soldier that the Saudi desert was not much different from Texas, the soldier politely disagreed. ``It's a little bit different,'' he said. Baker arrived in Bahrain, the financial hub of the Persian Gulf, after a 15-hour flight from Washington. He was whisked immediately by helicopter across the border to eastern Saudi Arabia, passing over camels running wild in the desert. There, at a location censored by Baker's staff, he addressed and mingled with the soldiers from the First Cavalry Division out of Fort Hood, Texas. They are among more than 110,000 defending the Saudi oil fields and are equipped with M-1 tanks, Bradley fighting vehicles, a multilaunch rocket system and shoulder-fired Stinger missiles. ``This is a long way from home,'' Baker told the troops. ``But I think that Americans are home wherever our principles are. And that's really what this crisis is all about.'' As he stepped down from the podium to mingle, a soldier took the microphone and to the accompaniment of the division band, sang Lee Greenwood's song: ``I'm Proud To Be an American.'' Afterward, Baker told reporters traveling with him: ``I was pleased to see that the morale is good. They all seemed to be upbeat. The main question is what the future holds. That is something that cannot be answered with any specificity.'' Baker said as he flew here Saturday he was laying the foundation for stronger economic and political measures against Iraq or even military action. ``Unprovoked aggression should not be rewarded. Unprovoked aggression should not be permitted to succeed,'' Baker told the troops in what has become a familiar refrain since Saddam Hussein conquered Kuwait and seized its oil fields in a blitzkrieg invasion Aug. 2. ``The world made a terrible mistake in the '30s when we were unable or refused to stand up to unprovoked aggression.'' Here he met with leaders of the ruling royal family of this wealthy ministate, which has strong ties to Kuwait - Sheik Isa bin Saman Al Khalifa, the emir of Bahrain; Sheik Khalifa bin Sulman; and Sheik Mohammed bin Mubarak Al Khalifa - to go over various scenarios to evict Iraq, including use of force. A U.S. official, briefing reporters afterward, said Bahrain would like the sanctions to get the job done, but military action was ``one of the options responsible governments have to study.'' There are 9,000 U.S. troops in Bahrain. The country also has sent its own small ground contingent to Saudi Arabia and made its air force available. Information minister Tariq Almoayed spoke in terms of resolve and supported strong statements being made by American officials. ``There is no reason to have all these armies from around the world here and tie their hands,'' he said. ``Everybody in this part of the world, I think, feels all of these armies from all the world are not here for a picnic.'' This was the first business session undertaken by the emir since he was hospitalized in October with an undisclosed ailment, and it took place at a hospital where the ruler has been recuperating. On Monday, Baker goes to Saudi Arabia, the linchpin of the Arab alliance against Saddam. There, official Kuwaiti sources told The Associated Press that the timing of military action against Iraq may be discussed. Baker will go first to Taif to see Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, the exiled emir, who on Saturday called for mobilization of a global effort to evict Iraq from Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Leftist Guerrillas Kill Mayor
DOC.TEXT: Leftist guerrillas have kidnapped and assassinated the mayor of a southern town. He was the ninth mayor slain this year, and the army has blamed most of the deaths on the rebels. The defense minister was quoted Sunday as saying the violence was hurting prospects for a negotiated peace between the government and leftist insurgents. The body of Edmundo Munoz, mayor of the southern town of Rosas, was found Saturday, less than 24 hours after guerrillas from the Simon Bolivar Coordination had kidnapped him, according to an army statement. The guerrilla organization is an umbrella for two leftist groups - the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia or FARC, and the National Liberation Army, or ELN. Guerrillas have been known to kidnap and sometimes kill local officials who refused to cooperate. The army, meanwhile, continues to fight the insurgents in several regions. One soldier and four members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces were killed Saturday in the southern state of Putumayo, the army statement said. The statment said an unspecified number of Liberation Army members were killed Saturday in northern Colombia when the army attacked rebel camps. ``The FARC and the ELN are showing through their terrorist actions that they do not want peace,'' said Defense Minister Oscar Botero in comments published Sunday by El Espectador newspaper. The rebel groups have said in recent weeks they are prepared to begin peace talks with the administration of President Cesar Gaviria in exchange for participating in next year's rewriting of the country's constitution. But Gaviria has ruled out participation in the constitutional assembly for rebels who do not accept a government peace plan. Members of the April 19 Movement, the only rebel group to lay down its weapons under the plan, are expected to win several of the 70 assembly seats in December elections. Another group, the National People's Army, has begun negotiations with the government.

DOC.HEAD: Jackson Likely To Have Limited Rights As Shadow Senator
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Jackson is heavily favored to win election as a ``shadow senator'' for the District of Columbia on Tuesday, but he's likely to find the doors locked when he gets to Congress. Jackson is one of 11 candidates vying for two ``shadow senator'' positions. He's making his first bid for elective office other than two unsuccessful runs for the Democratic presidential nomination. The non-paying ``shadow senators'' will lobby Congress to grant statehood to the District of Columbia. But by precedent and custom, only senators elected by one of the 50 states are given floor rights in the Senate and office space in the Capitol complex. ``Senator Mitchell has asked staff to look into precedent, and no decision has been made,'' on whether Jackson will be granted floor privileges, said Diane Dewhurst, a spokeswoman for Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell. The district also will elect a new non-voting delegate to Congress, with Democrat Eleanor Holmes Norton favored over Republican Harry Singleton. But while the delegate's House seat is non-voting, it is officially recognized, and the winner will get an office, floor privileges and the right to vote in committee. Going back to the 1790s, when the Tennessee territory first used the ``shadow'' concept to lobby for statehood, no one elected to such a post has been granted the rights of elected members of Congress. The last time a ``shadow'' legislator was used was by Alaska, which became the 49th state in 1959. Jackson brushes aside questions about the rights a shadow lawmaker would have. ``It's a matter of understanding, mainly, making the Senate and the House realize that there are over 600,000 people in this city who pay taxes, go to war, but don't have voting representation on Capitol Hill,'' he said last week. ``It is a fundamental issue of fairness.'' District of Columbia voters first approved sending a ``shadow'' delegation to Congress in 1980, but the city council twice postponed scheduled elections for the positions. This year, after aggressive lobbying by Jackson, the 13-member council gave the go-ahead. But because of concerns over the city's $100 million deficit, the council killed a bill that would have provided $1.3 million for office rental and staff for the two ``shadow'' senators and a ``shadow'' House member.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats See Racism In GOP Campaign Tactics
DOC.TEXT: Democrats on Sunday accused Republicans of racism in the North Carolina Senate race as a federal judge scheduled an election-eve hearing on whether the GOP's tactics are intimidating voters. Republican officials dismissed allegations that voter mailings in North Carolina and Texas were designed to intimidate minority or elderly voters. But U.S. District Judge Dickinson Debevoise scheduled a hearing for Monday in Newark, N.J., to determine whether the Republican National Committee is violating a 1982 consent decree that bars voter intimidation. The hearing was requested by the Democratic National Committee. ``What the Republican Party has done is absolutely disgusting,'' Democratic party Chairman Ronald Brown said on CBS-TV's ``Face the Nation.'' He accused the GOP of trying to ``intimidate the poorest and most vulnerable voters.'' The controversy has centered primarily on North Carolina, where Republican Sen. Jesse Helms is in a neck-and-neck race with Democrat Harvey Gantt, who is black. At issue are 150,000 official-looking postcards that the North Carolina GOP sent to predominantly minority Democratic precincts. Labeled ``Voter Registration Bulletin,'' the cards read, in part, that is a federal crime ``to knowingly give false information about your name, residence or period of residence to an Election Official.' ``We knew that in a panic Jesse Helms would turn to this kind of tactic, just as Republicans have done in the past,'' Brown said. Voter mailings also have been sent out in Texas to predominantly elderly Democratic voters, encouraging them to forego absentee ballots. Charles Black, a spokesman for the Republican National Committee, said he had not seen any of the mailings but insisted the GOP has never broken the consent decree on voter intimidation. The committee ``always plays by the rules,'' he said. But he added that North Carolina has ``a long history of Democrats stealing elections.'' State and local leaders ``have a responsibility to take legal action to ensure the integrity of the ballot, and that's all that's going on there,'' he said. House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., disagreed with the Republicans. ``The campaign that Jesse Helms is running is not a lot different than the campaign that David Duke ran in Louisiana,'' Gephardt said. Duke is a former Ku Klux Klan leader who lost in Louisiana's open Senate primary in October. ``The message ... clearly has racial overtones. It is clearly designed to appeal to people's prejudice,'' Gephardt said on NBC's ``Meet the Press.'' In the Helms-Gantt contest, Democrats also have charged Helms with playing on racial stereotypes in television advertisements. White House chief of staff John Sununu insisted the Bush administration and the GOP oppose any use of race in elections. ``I think in any campaign a racial message of one kind or the other is inappropriate and abhorrent,'' Sununu said. ``This administration has worked awfully hard to get that kind of aspect out of any campaign.'' Sununu noted that the Republican hierarchy, including President Bush, had disavowed Duke. But he sidestepped questions about Helms, for whom Bush has campaigned. Black said the Democrats' charges were old hat. ``You can always tell when the Democrats are about to have a bad political year because the weekend before the election they start acting like martyrs and screaming racism and voter intimidation,'' he said. At Monday's hearings in Newark, the federal judge is expected to examine whether the RNC violated a 1982 decree issued after the party reportedly hired armed guards to watch over various polling places in New Jersey.

DOC.HEAD: United Front Needed Against Iraq, Belgium Says
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Belgium called Sunday for a special European Community meeting to discuss the threat to unity posed by a slew of missions to Baghdad to try to obtain the release of hostages. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein ``is creating this royal court of all sorts of Western pilgrims who visit him to obtain the release of hostages,'' Belgian Foreign Minister Mark Eyskens told BRT television. Iraq has held thousands of foreigners hostage since its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. It has moved some to strategic locations to serve as shields against attack, and released others. Eyskens' comments came after he was asked about former West German chancellor Willy Brandt's scheduled trip to to Iraq on Monday. He said sometimes visiting officials or ex-officials ``let themselves be lured into political discussions'' with Saddam. Such talks, he said, could ``jeopardize the united stand'' against Iraq's takeover of Kuwait. Eyskens said he hoped an EC meeting could strengthen the allies' position on such initiatives. He said the meeting, requested by Belgium and the Netherlands, could be held Tuesday or Wednesday in Rome, when the trade bloc's foreign minister gather for an unrelated ceremony. EC officials in Rome could not confirm when or if the meeting would take place. Eyskens noted that the 12 community states had agreed last week to refrain from solitary missions to Iraq, in order to maintain the trade bloc's credibility and cohesion. Days later, Brandt's trip was announced. ``We just decided on a clear position that there would be no government delegations, directly or indirectly, traveling to Iraq to negotiate about the hostages,'' said Eyskens. Germany maintained Brandt's visit remained within the EC framework since he would would work for the release of all foreign hostages, not just Germans. The Bonn government defended Brandt's trip again Sunday, saying it wished him success. In another such visit, former Japanese Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone met with Saddam on Sunday. He said afterward it was too soon to tell if his efforts would help win the hostages' freedom. But the visit was potentially embarrassing for Japan. Nakasone emerged from the talks saying Saddam appeared to be earnest in his wish for peace. Hours later, Iraq's information minister told reporters Iraq would go to war rather than give up Kuwait. Iraq's official news agency also said Nakasone had told Saddam the Japanese parliament was unlikely to approve the sending of Japanese troops to the gulf. Nakasone did not disclose any such assurances, but the report made it appear that Japan might be willing to make concessions for its citizens' freedom. Eyskens said even if visits like Brandt's and Nakasone's were technically private ones, Saddam was well aware of the influence such figures have. ``When an important ex-politician goes to Baghdad to talk with Saddam it inevitably has a political character,'' he said. ``Increasingly, more tiny cracks appear in the Western front'' because of such initiatives. Eyskens also criticized former British Prime Minister Edward Heath for his visit to Iraq last month. He secured the release of 33 Britons and 14 U.S. citizens, but the Belgian official said there was a price. Following Heath's trip ``his views were, `Saddam isn't all that bad, we have to talk with him. His territorial claims (on Kuwait) can be partially defended.' That is language which is not conform to the Western front,'' Eyskens said. Iraq last week freed more than 250 French hostages while praising what it said were France's good-faith efforts to settle the crisis.

DOC.HEAD: Football Field In Saudi Is Unique: Tents and Sand
With AM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: It's probably the only such football field in the world: covered by sand with cot-filled tents running along one sideline. But the Marines on a rare day off Sunday didn't mind the dust. ``It's fun, a good way to let out aggressions,'' said Lance Cpl. Dale ``Tom'' Keller, 20, of Prineville, Ore. ``It's better than sitting back at camp doing nothing.'' Rest and relaxation for the 220,000 U.S. troops confronting Iraq in the Persian Gulf has become more important with Operation Desert Shield in its third month and no end in sight. Saudi Arabia is the first potential combat zone where some traditional sldiers' diversions - visiting area bars and dating the locals - are banned. In their absence, sports have become an important recreation, especially for the 30,000 Marines. Unlike their Army and Air Force counterparts, the Marines are barred from Saudi cities to keep a low profile. The Marines play football in a stadium at a base turned over to them by the Saudi government. Every game is called the Scud Bowl, apparently after Scud missiles which are part of the Iraqi arsenal. Dust bowl would be more like it. Even though clouds of dust partially obscured some of the play, the 100 fans at Sunday's main battle between the 174th Marine Wing Support Squadron and the 311th Marine Fighter Attack Squadron yelled just like fans at home. They cheered good passes and touchdowns, booed interceptions, and shouted at the referee for calls they didn't like. The Marines were playing flag football, a variation of touch football in which tackles are made by grabbing strips worn by the opposing team. Highlights of the game, which the 311th won 15-14, were broadcast on the Armed Forces Radio Network. Most fans sat in the stadium on one side of the field. But some stood outside a long row of tents running the length of the other side, just a few yards from the players. ``Just step right out and watch the game,'' said Lance Cpl. Ellory Myers, 20, of Casper, Wyo., whose tent is on the 40-yard line. ``It's a good bonus ... except when it wakes you up,'' he said. ``It's kind of fun, especially when people get in fights and stuff.'' ``Ringside seat,'' said Master Sgt. Dan Rich, 38, of Rochester, New York, a maintenance chief with the 311th Tom Cats. ``You get to holler at everybody. ... It's good for relieving stress.'' But not everyone cares for the tentside view, though. Lance Cpl. Wayne Lewis, 21, of Reading, Penn., who lives on the 50-yard line, said he wasn't interested in football and was annoyed the Marines hadn't put up the tents elsewhere. ``You get a lot of dust in your house, and they wake me up around 8 a.m.,'' he said. Chief Warrant Officer Jerry L. Duck, 36, of Malden, Miss., was celebrating a 16-0 shutout by officers over the enlisted men from his unit in the 311th. ``For an old man, I did all right,'' he said. ``It helps the morale. I think the stadium is the best place in the country.'' ``This is great,'' said Sgt. John Crone, 23, of York, Penn., a photographer for the 174th. ``A lot of Marines out here have it really bad off. They're out in the sand and the dirt. I kind of feel guilty sometimes.'' The stadium also has volleyball nets, a softball diamond, ping-pong tables and movies. Capt. Cindy Stock, 29, a flight nurse from Pope Air Force Base, N.C., was wearing shorts Sunday. ``It's one of the very few places we can wear them, which makes it doubly nice for women,'' she said. U.S. soldiers have been advised to try not to offend local residents. In Saudi Arabia, the Moslem way of life dictates that women not drive or expose their skin to public view. Sweating in a T-shirt and shorts during a break in another game, Lance Cpl. Darren Ortiz of New York City said it was like playing on the beach. ``You can run as hard as you can, but you won't move nowhere that fast.''

DOC.HEAD: Syrian Tanks Arrive on Saudi Soil to Check Iraq
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
LaserPhoto DHA5
DOC.TEXT: Syrian tanks and the lead elements of a infantry division landed Sunday in Saudi Arabia to join the Arab forces sent to the region in response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Saudi Prince Khalid, commander of all Arab troops deployed in the sands south of Iraq and Kuwait, saluted and warmly greeted the Syrian troops. ``We are all here to fight if it's necessary,'' said Khalid, commander of the Saudi air force and nephew of King Fahd. ``We are all in the same line,'' Khalid said at a dockside news conference. ``It is really a pleasure to have a Syrian armored division here. That makes me very happy.'' The Syrian troops ``will be under the Saudi flag,'' the prince said. But he noted they have ``a direct line'' to their president, Hafez Assad. Maj. Gen. Ali Habib, commander of Syrian troops in Saudi Arabia, refused to answer questions. But a spokesman said between 2,500 and 3,000 troops were aboard the cargo ship Saudi Qassim. The remaining elements of the 15,000-member 9th Armored Division would arrive in the next few weeks, Saudi officials said. The Syrian vanguard consisted of Soviet-made T-62 tanks, which are standard fighting armor for Syria but not the top-of-the-line model sold by Moscow. The Iraqis have 500 T-72 tanks, which have more firepower and range. Ten of the tanks were parked in formation on trailers. Their four-man tank crews and a company of 120 infantrymen, carrying chemical masks and AK-47 assault rifles, snapped to attention. Two tanks roared off the cargo vessel following a stiff-gaited color guard, and members of the ship's crew said 145 tanks remained in the belly of the ship. Syria has pledged to send 270 tanks. The Syrians also brought radar-guided anti-aircraft vehicles. The tanks, which sailed a week ago from the Mediterranean port of Tartous, are the first Syrian armor to be sent. The armor will reinforce 4,000 ground troops who earlier planted their battle flag alongside fellow Arabs in the Saudi sands. The original force was made up of elite Special Forces who have fought the Israelis and others in Lebanon. When asked if he thought Syrian troops would fight Iraqis, Khalid said, ``Let's hope (they can be used) to prevent war.'' He called their arrival ``a great contribution from a brother country to defend the kingdom.'' About 300,000 troops, mostly Americans, make up the multinational force. Khalid spoke in Arabic to the Syrian troops, saying that Iraq's Aug. 2 conquest of Kuwait was wrong and would be punished by God. ``There is One who sees everything,'' Khalid said, according to an intepreter. ``We are all sure his hand will come very soon.''

DOC.HEAD: The Western Ellis Island Not As Warmly Remembered
DOC.TEXT: The 50th anniversary of the closing of Angel Island, gateway into the United States for thousands of Chinese immigrants, won't be marked with the flourish that celebrated the restoration of Ellis Island. Both islands were immigration stations, Ellis Island in New York Harbor and Angel Island in San Francisco Bay. But no Statue of Liberty greeted the 175,000 Chinese who immigrated via Angel Island between 1910 and 1940. Angel Island is regarded by many Chinese not as a gateway but as a prison where many were held for months before being allowed entrance to the United States. In fact, it is near Alcatraz, the island prison. For them, the closing of the station on Nov. 5, 1940, represents a ``first step toward the healing process,'' said Paul Chow, whose father was kept on Angel Island for six months. No big event was planned to commemorate Monday's anniversary, but neither does the Chinese community want to forget. ``I think it would be a big mistake to forget,'' said Phil Choy, a San Francisco architect whose father immigrated from China. A small celebration was planned on the mainland to remember the island's place in U.S. immigration history, Chow said. Chow has led volunteer tours of the Angel Island barracks for 18 years and has been the leader of a historical advisory committee that has fought to restore the site. The island is maintained as a park and is accessible by ferry. He invited immigration officials on a tour recently to urge them to include the island in a centennial celebration next year of the founding of the Immigration and Naturalization Service. ``Having seen it, we'd like to do something to let people know more about it,'' said Connie Mackey, co-director of the INS centennial committee. A 1980 collection of poems, titled ``Island,'' records poetry the Chinese carved into the walls of their wooden barracks. And a documentary, called ``Carved in Silence'' after the poems, started distribution in 1988. In the documentary, Lee Puey You described her first encounter with the United States. ``I had to take off all my clothes. It was so embarrassing and shameful for me. Back in China, I never had to take off everything. But it was different here in America. I found it very strange.''

DOC.HEAD: Benazir Bhutto and Husband Take National Assembly Oaths
DOC.TEXT: Former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto and her husband - both facing legal battles - took the oath of office in the National Assembly on Sunday in the fifth civilian government in 43 years. Asif Ali Zardari, 38, charged with kidnapping and extortion, was freed from jail to attend the ceremony but must return when the assembly session ends next week. Ms. Bhutto, who boycotted Saturday's session to protest her husband's absence, faces seven charges of misconduct before special one-judge tribunals probing political corruption during her 20 months in power. She said she is worried about her husband's treatment. ``They're keeping him in exactly the same conditions as when there was martial law. He has nothing,'' Ms. Bhutto, ousted Aug. 6. Zardari, jailed in the southern port city of Karachi since Oct. 10, said his lawyers told him not to talk to reporters. He was elected to represent a sprawling slum district in Karachi. He and Ms. Bhutto have denied any wrongdoing. Ms. Bhutto, 37, elected to represent Larkana in southern Sind Province, could be banished from politics for up to seven years if found guilty on any of the charges. Zardari could be sentenced to 15 years in jail if convicted of allegations he kidnapped a Pakistan-born Briton and extorted $800,000. It is expected Zardari will be staying in the Sehala guest house, where Ms. Bhutto and her mother, Nusrat, were imprisoned in 1978 after Ms. Bhutto's father was toppled in a coup. He was later hanged. Ms. Bhutto's Pakistan People's Party was routed in the Oct. 24 national elections, which she claims included widespread fraud. Her party and three allied groups won 45 seats in the 217-seat assembly. A right-wing coalition of 18 parties controls 105 seats and claims loyalty from 40 other legislators. They have nominated as prime minister 41-year-old industrialist Nawaz Sharif, who is expected to easily win the post Tuesday. The swearing-in ceremony is to take place later the same day. Gohar Ayub Khan, a coalition candidate, easily won the speaker's chair Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Minnesota Poll Shows Governor, GOP Challenger in Dead Heat
DOC.TEXT: A poll released Sunday showed Democratic Gov. Rudy Perpich virtually tied with Republican challenger Arne Carlson, who was put on the GOP ticket just last week. Perpich was favored by 39 percent of the likely voters surveyed and Carlson by 38 percent, according to the Pioneer Press-WCCO-TV Poll, Twenty-two percent were undecided and 2 percent favored other candidates. The survey was conducted last Monday through Thursday among 760 Minnesotans who indicated they are likely to vote Tuesday. The survey had a margin of error of 4 percentage points. Carlson was placed on the ballot after Republican nominee Jon Grunseth withdrew from the race last week because of allegations of sexual impropriety. Ten percent of the voters said the controversy over Grunseth will make them less likely to vote for other Republican candidates in Tuesday's election, enough to influence the outcome of a close race. Thirty-eight percent of those surveyed said they had an unfavorable impression of the governor and 45 percent had a favorable impression. And, by a margin of more than 2-to-1, voters agreed with the statement, ``it's time for a change in Minnesota's top elected officials.'' Among those people who said they wanted a change, Carlson led Perpich by a 55 percent to 17 percent margin.
DOC.HEAD: Kansas Poll Shows GOP Hayden Moving Ahead of Democrat Finney
DOC.TEXT: Republican Gov. Mike Hayden has opened a slight lead over Democratic challenger Joan Finney in the final days before Tuesday's election, according to a poll published Sunday. Forty-one percent of those surveyed either solidly backed Hayden or were leaning in his favor, compared to 36 percent for Mrs. Finney, according to the Topeka Capital-Journal's telephone survey of 1,000 registered voters. Eight percent favored independent candidate Christina Campbell-Cline, and 15 percent were undecided. The respondents described themselves as likely to go to the polls Tuesday. The margin of error was plus or minus 3 percentage points. Earlier polls by the newspaper showed Mrs. Finney with a 48 percent to 35 percent lead over Hayden in early September, and each candidate was backed by 37 percent of those surveyed early in October.
DOC.HEAD: Poll Shows Weld, Silber Neck-and-Neck In Massachusetts
DOC.TEXT: Republican William Weld has gained ground in the Massachusetts governor's race and now is running neck-and-neck with Democrat John Silber, according to a poll released Sunday. Silber was favored by 44 percent of those surveyed for the Boston Globe-WBX-TV and Weld by 41 percent. The poll's margin of error was 3 percentage points, making the race a statistical dead heat. Twelve percent were undecided and independent High Tech Candidate Len Umina was supported by 3 percent of those polled. ``We think we're going to catch him,'' Weld said. ``It's moving our way so quickly. Either we'll catch him this weekend or in the booth this Tuesday.'' Silber campaign officials said their internal polls show the Democrat ahead with the help of independents who have been moving to the Silber camp. In the U.S. Senate race, the poll showed Democratic Sen. John Kerry had pulled ahead of Republican rival James Rappaport by 20 percentage points, 55 percent to 35 percent. After the primary election, the two were in a virtual dead heat.
DOC.HEAD: Candidate Ends Up At Wedding, Not Meeting
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Senate hopeful Stephen Jones was amazed to find 100 cars parked at a church where he was to address the Kingfisher County Farm Bureau. Jones, who is running against Democratic Sen. David Boren, said he grabbed as many campaign brochures as he could carry and hurried inside. That's when he noticed some fellows bringing in champagne. ``Man, I thought, the Kingfisher County Farm Bureau has suddenly gotten a little more lively,'' Jones said. Then Jones spotted a three-tiered cake and men in tuxedos. ``It instantly dawned on me that I was at a wedding,'' he said. Jones said he returned to where he'd been passing out brochures and said, ``I'm David Boren,'' then walked out. He later learned the farm bureau meeting was in a church 18 miles to the north. ``I think I got their votes,'' Jones said of his church appearance. ``But I didn't get to kiss the bride or eat any of the cake.''

DOC.HEAD: Snow Reaches Southern Plains, Cold Invades Texas
DOC.TEXT: A snowstorm moved out of the Rockies and onto the Plains on Sunday, and rain fell along and behind a strong cold front stretching from Texas to the Midwest. At midday, snow was falling over southwestern Kansas, western Oklahoma including the Panhandle, and the northern Texas Panhandle. By mid-morning, 2{ inches of snow had fallen at Guyman, Okla., and 2 inches fell at Garden City, Kan. On Saturday, the storm produced 19{ inches of snow at Cuchara in south-central Colorado. At midday, the cold front extended across northwestern Ohio, west-central Indiana, south-central Missouri, southwestern Arkansas and western Texas. When the cold front moved through Corpus Christi, Texas, during the morning, wind shifted from out of the north and the temperature fell 13 degrees in one hour. A warning of freezing temperatures overnight and into Monday morning was posted for El Paso, Texas. Rain fell across southern Lower Michigan, northwestern Ohio, northern Indiana, northern and west-central Illinois, southeastern Iowa, Missouri, northwestern Arkansas, southeastern through south-central Kansas, and northern and central Oklahoma, and showers and thunderstorms reached along the lower Texas Gulf Coast and over southeastern Texas. Freezing rain was scattered over north-central Missouri. Rain also fell on northern Florida. Snow fell over eastern and central Idaho, and western Montana, with accumulations up to 8 inches possible at higher elevations Rain fell from northwestern California across western Oregon and western Washington state, western Idaho, and central Montana. Heaviest rainfall during the six hours up to 1 p.m. EST 1.62 inches at Paacious, Texas, and 1.02 inches at Fort Smith, Ark. In Alaska, a winter storm warning was posted through Monday over the Tanana Valley, west of Delta. Up to 8 inches of snow was possible on top of 8 inches that already had fallen. Fairbanks got 7 inches of snow in 24 hours. Sunday's low for the Lower 48 states was a record-tying 7 below zero at Laramie, Wyo. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 25 at Laramie to 87 in Florida at both Fort Myers and Tampa.

DOC.HEAD: South Africa on Road Back to Olympics
DOC.TEXT: African sports officials opened the door Sunday for South Africa's return to the international arena once apartheid is ended. They cautioned, however, at the close of their first direct meeting with South Africa sports organizers that non-negotiable conditions for re-entry will take time to put into effect. A communique specified that South African participants will not be allowed back into Olympic or international sports until the apartheid system of racial separation is ``completely eradicated'' and South Africa's disparate and segregated sports bodies are merged under non-racial banners. ``There can be no concessions on this,'' Jean Claude Ganga of the Congo told reporters after reading the communique. Ganga presided over the Harare gathering of 43 representatives of all major South African sports organizations and 14 officials of the African branch of the International Olympic Committee. The Association of National Olympic Committees of Africa, the main African Olympic organization, set up two steering committees charged with promoting and monitoring an end to apartheid in South African sports. ``We are happy with the discussions. The door has not been slammed shut,'' said Sam Ramsamy, chief of the South African Non-Racial Olympic committee. The participants agreed to establish an eight-member committee to coordinate reforms inside South Africa in liaison with an African monitoring committee scheduled to hold its first meeting in March. Ganga said the Africans were encouraged that a new era of dialogue with the South Africans and among South African sports people themselves was beginning. He said the South Africans showed willingness to work toward their country's return to the global sporting arena. ``I am convinced this is possible. It might take some time, but it is possible,'' Ganga said. He is president of the Association of National Olympic Committees of Africa. He said the International Olympic Committee asked his organization to review the 20-year international sports boycott of South Africa. South African sports organizers say political reforms introduced in South Africa this year by President F.W. de Klerk have improved their country's image enough to allow for an easing of world sports bans imposed by the IOC in 1970. Continuing reforms toward dismantling apartheid should enable South Africans to compete in the 1992 Olympics, the South Africans say. But African sports officials believe the pace of reform could admit South African athletes to the 1996 centenary games in Atlanta only if legalized racial segregation is abolished completely by then. De Klerk, head of South Africa's white-led government, has launched a program of social and political reform. He is negotiating with black groups to give majority blacks a say in the country's political system. South African delegates at the Harare talks represented all major sports in that country. They included senior rugby and cricket officials responsible in the past for circumventing the international sports boycott by organizing unofficial tours. The African officials said any future ``rebel'' tours would be viewed as a setback to restoring international recognition of South African sports.

DOC.HEAD: Marijuana Magazine Cloing After Decade
DOC.TEXT: Sinsemilla Tips, the magazine for marijuana growers, is going out of business after 10 years because of the nation's anti-drug climate, its publisher says. ``Drug hysteria and paranoia'' in the United States led to circulation declines for the quarterly magazine, publisher Tom Alexander of Corvallis said recently. The last issue of the periodical named for a potent strain of pot will be released this month. ``Ten months ago, our circulation was 20,000,'' he said of the quarterly printed in Portland. ``Now, it's 4,000.'' Alexander's store in Corvallis, Full Moon, also was hit during a nationwide series of raids on stores alleged to be selling equipment used for marijuana cultivation. First published in May 1980, Sinsemilla Tips was printed in Eugene until about 1986, then was printed in Portland. Labeling itself as a ``domestic marijuana journal,'' the magazine featured a variety of marijuana-related news, features and advice columns, as well as analysis of drug issues. The publication's circulation reached its peak of 20,000 in 1987 and maintained that level until last year, when the stepped-up government action against marijuana cultivation began to cut its magazine sales, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders American Submarine Out Of Brazilian Waters
DOC.TEXT: A judge ordered a U.S. submarine out of Brazilian waters, saying it poses an enviromental danger because it is nuclear-powered, news reports said Sunday. The judge in the northeastern coastal city of Recife ruled that the USS Greelings must withdraw to 200 miles from the Brazilian coast, outside territorial waters. The submarine is part of a naval task force docked in Recife, 1,500 miles northeast of Ro de Janeiro. The vessels are here for joint training maneuvers between the American and Brazilian navies. A Marine guard at the American consulate in Rio said no one was available to comment on the reports. The judge could not be reached for comment either. The judge's ruling was in response to a petition from an environmental group, the Rio newspaper Jornal do Brasil said. The judge reportedly ordered a $100,000 daily fine if the order is disobeyed.

DOC.HEAD: Agreement Reached Over Disputed Clovis Site Dig
DOC.TEXT: An archaeologist will resume digging at a site used by some of North America's earliest human inhabitants under an agreement with Indians concerned about what will be done with artifacts or human remains. The agreement was signed Friday by state officials, landowner Dr. Mack Richey, the Confederated Colville Tribes and Michael Gramly, dig director and curator of anthropology at the Museum of Science in Buffalo, N.Y. Gramly has a state permit to excavate the 11,200-year-old site, which has yielded stone and bone tools made in the style attributed to the so-called Clovis people. Clovis remains, identified by a particular style of fluted spear point, are named for a town in New Mexico where they were first identified in the 1930s. The dig, scheduled to resume last month, was put on hold when the Colvilles contended that Gramly's work in the orchard might disturb an ancestral burial ground. They also expressed concern about what would happen to any artifacts found. Under Friday's agreement, Gramly is to provide the Colvilles with a list and photographs of all artifacts found at the site. The state will pay a tribe member to be at the site while digging is under way, for consultation about artifacts unearthed there. Gramly has said there is little possibility the site contains human remains, and questions whether anyone now living can claim an ancestral link to the Clovis people. But he appeared pleased with the agreement. ``A few days ago I had had it. Today, I'm a little happier and maybe a little humbled. I'm believing in human beings again,'' he said. But he contended that the problems that have stalled his project may hinder funding for future efforts in the state. The agreement signed Friday will allow removal of 17 artifacts uncovered in a 1988 dig and completion of an exploratory trench. Gramly said he will remove some bone artifacts as soon as they are dry enough to be lifted. He said digging and site tours will continue over the next two to three weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Military Town Feels Economic Pinch With Soldiers Gone
DOC.TEXT: Since troops from Fort Hood started shipping out to Saudi Arabia, this military town has come to look like an economic casualty, as stores and restaurants close from a lack of business. ``Business is off 35 to 40 percent,'' said Mike Lazar, 53, owner of a topless nightclub that generally gets three-fourths of its business from soldiers at the nearby base. ``There are fewer soldiers, and those that come in are spending less,'' said Lazar. ``Why? The magic of the crowd is missing.'' The Western Sizzlin' Steakhouse closed last month because it lost so much business when the troops joined Operation Desert Shield in Saudi Arabia after of Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Manuel Pacheco plans to sell his Boot & Things Army Store. ``I don't know what my next move will be,'' said Pacheco. ``When you're not making enough to pay the light bill, it's time.'' Fort Hood's 38,000 troops - plus another 55,000 Army spouses and children - provide a livelihood for an estimated 120,000 civilians around Killeen, population 65,000.
